title: letters-let-us-vote-brexit-put-indy-back-burner
story: However, with regard to the Labour Party I think most people would agree that it has a contradictory and confusing policy which appears to change depending on the day of the week ndash hence why it is to focus on a domestic radical agenda rather than Brexit.Having said that it, is only the Conservative Party which can offer the UK voters a Brexit withdrawal agreementwith the EU and a proven economic track record going forward ndash especially for Scotland, with the real prospect of Freeports and access to a new trade deal with the US to avoid future penal sanctions enacted by President Trump against the EU on Scottish exports such as whisky.On the other hand we should expect the one-trick pony SNP to run a predictable election campaign and avoid any discussion on its dismal performance on devolved powers and focus instead entirely on its fancul promises about independence. For example the fact that Scotland has added around a further pound billion to its debt since  and become a ldquojohnny-come-lately Europeanwill not be up for public scrutiny.Furthermore, it would appear that tactical voting will play a major part on the outcome of the General Election with a number of people holding their noses to vote for the party which can deliver or safeguard either Brexit, Remain, the Union or an independence referendum. Under these circumstances surely the best outcome would be for an orderly Brexit and also for a Scottish referendum to be put on the back burner for at least a ldquogeneration to allow UK businessescertainty to invest for the future to the advantage of us all and not self-serving narrow nationalism either by the SNP or the Brexit Party.Ian Lakin, Aberdeen AB.IT is timely to remind the First Minister in particular and the SNP in general that sovereignty in Scotland is vested in the people and not in parliament. It is possible to win a majority of seats in Parliament, whether Holyrood or Westminster, by obtaining the votes of a minority of the electorate or a minority of votes cast this being an insubstantial basis to demand Scottish independence.William Durward, Bearsden.SO the fates have decreed that we get an early Christmas present in the form of a General Election. While the date is clear, it is less obvious for whom one should vote where one is not already a paid-up member or ardent supporter of one party or another. It has to be said that the selection of party leaders is not overly impressive. It has to be one of the poorest list of leaders promoting election campaigns in our history.For the Conservatives we have the incorrigible Boris Johnson, who has been known to be economical with the truth on occasion. For Labour we have Jeremy Corbyn, who was once vocal in his support of Venezuela. The current tragic condition of that country illustrates how dangerous the implementation of his doctrinaire socialist policies would be for the UK.The Lib Dems have the opportunistic Jo Swinson, lacking in gravitas, who sees herself, somewhat delusionally, as the next Prime Minister. For the SNP we have the doughty Ian Blackford, the investment banker, living the le of a ldquosimple crofter. His party at Westminster basically and repetitively sings from one song sheet . Do not let us forget the ex-Ukip leader Nigel Farage, now calling the shots for the Brexit Party. In spite of all the predictions of the subsequent profound adverse effects, he would prefer to leave the European Union without a deal.While not being spoiled for choice with regard to the leadership qualities of those at the head of parties and their policies, more and more I have inclined to the view that there is a case for extending the choice available on the list of candidates on the ballot paper,by adding a box to be crossed with the wording ldquonone of the aboversquo.Ian W Thomson, Lenzie.PLEASE help our memories by answering the following questions:. What were the reasons for the Brexit referendum ndash apart from David Cameronrsquos promise to hold it . Have we ever seen the full details of Boris Johnsonrsquos deal accepted by the rest of Europe  . Has a Prime Minister ever stood for election after two courts found him guilty of misrepresentation of advice to a monarch Bryce Drummond, Kilmarnock.WHAT action has been taken regarding reports that the First Minister is was using her personal SNP email accountto conduct government business  If true, this could be a very serious matter as developments in the United States have proved.Government business records are not the property of any official or party, they belong to the people and should be open, either immediately or after designated periods of time depending on security, to public scrutiny. Letrsquos hope nothing in this personal account which may be of public interest has been binned.W MacIntyre, East Kilbride.Read more: MSPs tell Sturgeon to rewrite Indyref law

title: msps-back-plans-tackle-euro-2020-ticket-touts
story: Members of the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Culture Committee unanimously approved legislation designed to protect fans from paying for rip-off tickets.The Uefa Championship Bill was introduced at Holyrood last month as Glasgow prepares to host fixtures as part of the tournament next yearIt will prohibit the unauthorised sale of tickets for the tournament which are in excess of face value or with a view to making a profit.Other measures in the Bill include the banning of unauthorised street trading and unauthorised advertising in event zones in the city.Criminal offences will also be createdfor ticket touting, unauthorised street trading and advertising, with enforcement officers given powers to tackle such offences.Exemptions will be made to allow activities such as busking and collections for charity within designated fan zones during the competition.Committee convener Joan McAlpine said: ldquoThe committee recognises the signicant cultural, economic and social opportunities that hosting part of Euro  presents to Scotland.ldquoThe Bill provides the tools necessary to make sure the event is a success and the committee unanimously supports the principles of the Bill.ldquoIt is welcoming to see that action will be taken to allow buskers and charity collectors to operate during the tournament.ldquoTravelling football fans are in for a real treat when they visit and soak up the unique atmosphere that will be created.Deputy committee convener Claire Baker added: ldquoThe committee has considered this Bill to an extremely tight timescale in recognition of the benefit that hosting Euro  matches will bring to Scotland.ldquoTicket touting is an unacceptable act which takes advantage of fans. The committee fully supports the measures proposed which send a clear message that such actions should become a thing of the past.

title: herald-view-voters-deserve-derision-denunciation-deceit
story: Thatrsquos because the central issue, Brexit, is by its nature isive. In Scotland, we have the additional but equally isive issue of independence. Current polling and conventional wisdom suggest that the Conservatives should obtain a majority across England and Wales, and the SNP will perform very strongly in Scotland. But as the last general election campaign and the current unreliability of polling have shown, those apparent positions could be quite dferent by December .There are the usual unforeseeable factors of any campaign: blunders by candidates, external events, issues other than those the parties anticipatecoming to the fore. Even without those, however, the arithmetic is fiendishly tricky to calculate. No one knows the degree to which, for example, support for the Conservatives ndash or, for that matter, many Labour MPs ndash may be undermined by the Brexit Party. Nor the extent to which tactical voting against Brexit may benefit the Liberal Democrats or the SNP.It is assumed that the strength of Remain sentiment bodes well for the Nationalists, but  per centis not a negligible proportion of the electorate ndash itrsquos more than the SNP secured at the last general election, when they took  per cent of the countryrsquos Westminster seats. Andthe focus turns from Brexit to a second independence referendum, it is as likely that Unionists will vote tactically as it is that Remain and Leave voters will. Given the number of marginal seats, how hotly they will be contested, and the first-past-the-post system, any of the parties could see gains being offset by losses.The picture is just as unclear where in the UK splits in either the Leave or Remain votes could allow unexpected gains for almost any party. Butpoliticians and their most vehement supporters can have no certainty about the results, nor should they claim a monopoly on the truth, or moral virtue, of their arguments.One expects candidates and activists to paint themselves in the best light, and their opponents in the worst, but ision should not be exploited to mislead and to coarsen public discourse. Even before the campaigns have begun, there have been unpleasant instances of abuse ndash and equally dangerous attempts to claim robust criticism, within the normal bounds of political speech, amounts to abuse. There may be little prospect of restraining the more extreme rhetoric which appears on social media, but the electorate deserve an effort from those who seek their vote to conduct themselves honestly, and to give consideration in their thinking, rhetoric and pledges to those who may vehemently disagree with their position.Division may be unavoidable we may also fail, in the end, to get a genuinely decisive result. But it ought not to be too much to ask for an election campaign conducted on all sides without derision, denunciation and deceit.Lord Provosts resignationWhen is an lsquoerror of judgementrsquo a quitting matter in our largely discredited world of politics  Glasgowrsquos Lord Provost Eva Bolanderrsquo pound, expenses for her nails and  pairs of shoes caused embarrassment in the corridors of power but she retained the full support of the SNP city council leader and the First Minister.Days later, a General Election is called and she is a now seen as an electoral liability hence her lsquoresignationrsquo . Pity doing the right thing only appears to count when it is politically expedient.Imagine Rev I.M. Jolly on social mediaAsThought for the Day were not bad enough, a new menace has emerged in the form of the ldquoInstagram Vicar. A Church of England vicar, Chris Lee, has added , followers on the  to his parishioners in west London, and earned comparisons with TV comedy Fleabagrsquos ldquohot priest for his mission to ldquoinvade social media with a message of hope. We can only regret that the Rev I.M. Jolly, Scotlandrsquos own master of the media homily, did not survive into the age of Instagram, or add Twitter, Facebook and Snapchat to the outlets for his inspirational spiritual message. Think of the lols. Not.

title: prince-charles-borders-visit-marks-textiles-renaissance
story: The industry in the Borders stretches as far back as the th century, with Hawick the cashmere capital of the world, with yarn to make it coming from goats thousands of miles to the east, on the Tibetan plateau.It was when merchant James Hardie introduced the first knitting machines to Hawick in  that the woollen industry really took off.The Pringle brand began le in , with Barrie, Innes Henderson, Lyle  Scott, Peter Scott and many others following.The town has a long association with the worldrsquos most famous designers, from Dior, Bernat Klein and Chanel to Vivienne Westwood and Clements Ribiero.But the industry saw a downturn in the late th century due to overseas competition, and the latest body blow came in March when Hawick Knitwear, with a history stretching back  years, finally closed with the loss of  jobs.Now after decades of decline, knitwear firm Scott and Charters - to whom London luxury goods firm William  Son entrusts its cashmere production - has opened a new state-of-the-art factory.It is said to be the first new factory to be built in Hawick in over  years.And on Friday, Prince Charles donned a traditional green kilt as saw the companys mill in action during a visit to the Borders, before officially opening the new factory, the first to be built in the town in  years.Malcolm Grant, managing director of Scott and Charters said: "It was very important to the management team that the business remained in the heart of the Burnfoot community in Hawick, where it has been based for more than  years, and to see the community come out this morning to welcome HRH was wonderful."The Scottish knitwear industry has gone through a very tough period over the last  years, however those companies which have ridden the storm have re-thought their businesses in order to not only survive in todayrsquos market, but thrive in it.:How a crazy idea helped save Borders textiles jobs"There is a steady flow of fashion houses, designers and quality retailers ing to knock on the doors of British manufacturers, seeking products with an inherent integrity and tradition for quality. So this investment is a real statement of support and belief in both Scott  Charters and its workforce, and equally importantly the Scottish knitwear industry and British manufacturing.Hawick and Denholm councillor Stuart Marshall described it as a " fantastic day for Hawick and more importantly for Scott and Charters".He said: "Our town has suffered so many job losses throughout the industry over the years, but todays opening ceremony of this fantastic modern new factory is in my mind a ringing endorsement of how this rollercoaster industry is now bouncing back."Im absolutely delighted that such an investment and indeed commitment has been made in this sector."This factory is now leading the way in being energy efficient and everyone is thrilled to see so many jobs being protected .It is a shot in the arm for an industry that took a hit after workers at Hawick Knitwear, once one of the largest knitwear firms in the UK, were given bleak lunchtime news in March that -day consultation period over redundancy was being launched.The business had previously been saved from the axe by a management buyout in .However, in January  it went into administration with the loss of  jobs.Later the same year, Lyber, a group formed by Hong Kong-based Artwell, bought some assets, the firmrsquos name and intellectual property, securing  jobs in the process.At that time, then Scottish Government business minister Fergus Ewing called it ldquogreat news for Hawick and the textile industry in the Borders, adding: ldquoThe sale is testament to the quality of the product and the demand for knitwear from this part of Scotland.But today couturiers and designers from Italy, France, Londonrsquos Savile Row and Highland estates are still regular visitors to Hawickrsquos mills.And the continuing importance of textiles to the Borders was highlighted with the opening in March of a Centre of Excellence in Textiles in Hawick, developed to tackle what Scottish Borders Council described as a critical skills shortage hampering companiesrsquo efforts to boost their productivity.The first trainees are learning hand finishing and machine skills, following research commissioned by the project steering group into the areas of most demand for local textiles businesses.:Chanel and the Scottish textile industryFellow Hawick councillor Watson McAteer added: "This new factory has replaced an existing family owned business providing new jobs and a bright future in the largest housing estate in the Borders."It has been quite an incredible journey to see the fortunes of the knitwear industry change over recent years with a worrying trend of closures being replaced by substantial investment in the production of high quality knitwear for a world-wide market."The fantastic new Scott and Charters factory is at the cutting edge of an industry that continues to dominate the economic future of Hawick and the substantial investment has provided a real confidence boost and endorsement for a highly skilled local workforce."Mark Rowley, Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive member for business and economic development, added: ldquoIt is fantastic to see the first knitwear factory to be built for  years open in Hawick and I look forward to Scott and Charters contributing to the townrsquos world renowned textiles and knitwear industry.ldquoHopefully the opening of Scott and Charters, the initial success of the Centre of Excellence and the launch of Made in Hawick quality mark will give our textiles industry the confidence to grow and thrive.

title: ancient-celtic-healing-well-gets-long-awaited-spring-clean
story: But the modern world of backpackers and coach tours has taken its toll on Clootie Well in Munlochy, the Black Isle, where legend has it a rag or cloot dipped in the healing waters and tied to a tree can cure sickness or ailment.Now officials from Forestry and Land Scotland have teamed up with community groups for one of Scotlandrsquos most unusual clean-up operations.In a bid to preserve the site and protect the environment, they removed  bags of unsuitable offerings last month, including underwired bras, polyester flags, umbrellas, sunglasses ndash and even a medical back brace.But locals were careful to maintain the unique atmosphere of a place steeped in mystery and long associated with pre-Christian traditions.John Stott, chair of the local Knockbain Community Council, said the woods surrounding the well had become a mess.He said: ldquoIt had got out of control, and the cloots werenrsquot actually biodegradable, by and large.ldquoA lot of the material, as most modern materials are now, wasnrsquot biodegradable, therefore itrsquos never going to go anywhere.Mr Stott said the site had expanded as it grew more popular with backpackers and tour companies.He said: ldquoIt had started to spread out to the point where it was taking over a huge section of woodland, as opposed to the actual Clootie Well site itself, which is, letrsquos say,  yards by  yards or something like that.ldquoThe cloots had actually extended out to  or  yards. It was just a huge expansion of the site.ldquoBut at the actual site round the Clootie Well itself, we didnrsquot remove anything other than possibly inappropriate stuff such as umbrellas, sunglasses, a pair of trainers.ldquoThere was a colossal amount of stuff around that was totally inappropriate.However, Mr Stott said those involved were careful to show respect to people who had placed genuine offerings around the well.He added: ldquoItrsquos peoplersquos wishes, peoplersquos hopes, obviously, that they are hanging on these trees.ldquoWe did it with as much respect and dignity as we possibly could.He continued: ldquoThe idea basically is you hang up a wee bit of cloth, and as that cloth biodegrades it draws away the illness of the person who you have hung it up for.ldquoSo thatrsquos the theory,you like, or the history of it. But things like sunglasses are clearly never, ever going to biodegrade.He said those who initially expressed concerns over the clean-up were reassured once the purpose of it was made clear.And he suggested an annual drive to keep the surrounding area tidy could be in order in future.He added: ldquoI wouldnrsquot quite say we havenrsquot scratched the surface, but Irsquom quite sure the same exercise could be done again and it still wouldnrsquot actually affectthe character.ldquoI would like to see some kind of annual event ndash done tastefully, done as a family thing, just to make sure that we keep on top of the non-biodegradables and we donrsquot end up back in the same situation.Clootie wells ndash or sites drawing on similar traditions ndash can be found where in Scotland and the UK, but few possess the unsettling atmosphere found in Munlochy.Its strange power even inspired elements of Ian Rankinrsquos novel The Naming of the Dead.While it is associated with a holy well, such healing traditions pre-date Christianityand the area has become an important site for those with a iety of beliefs and none.Maree Morrison, of Forestry and Land Scotland, said  volunteers took part in the clean-up from the local communities of Munlochy, Avoch and Knockbain, as well as from further across the Black Isle and Easter Ross.She said: ldquoThe site was expanding rapidly, with the surrounding woodland being badly affected by non-biodegradable items as they built up over the years.ldquoThere were cloots tied around trees and information posts in the car park.ldquoThe items had crept out from the well up to  metres out into the woodland, and the local community felt that it was getting too much and was detracting from the traditional nature of the healing well.Ms Morrison said volunteers removed a iety of unsuitable items including empty dog poo bags, entire pairs of jeans, a window blind and even an electrical sander.Forestry and Land Scotland is now requesting that any offerings left at the site are restricted to natural cotton or wool. Any plastics, polyesters or other materials will be removed.

title: tom-gordon-sturgeons-pitch-voters-may-not-survive-spotlight
story: But elections are like the old joke about making God laugh. How to do it  Tell him your plans. This election, already as flaky and unpredictable as any I can remember, will not be dictated by the crossed fingers of party leaders.Try as they might to plot a particular course, they will be buffeted and blown about. Events, the Kryptonite of politics, come thick and fast in elections, and this one promises events galore.Mr Johnsonrsquos decision to press ahead for a Christmas poll already looks ropey. Nigel Farage and the Brexit party threw him for a loop yesterday with a choice between a pro-Brexit pact endorsed by Donald Trump or a split Leave vote.The PM has also had to grin weakly through multiple TV interviews about his failure to get Brexit done by October  despite his do-or-die bravado.The doubters, the doomsters, the gloomsters, they got it right. He failed. He may try to blame parliament, but itrsquos the same parliament that was there when he made his promise. His sales pitch in the Tory leadership contest was that he, uniquely, could break the impasse. Boris the Bold was supposed to wrestle MPs into submission or toss them out the ring and get some new ones. Instead they gave the gloating grappler an octave-raising wedgie.The relentless nature of election campaigning means party leaders are never able to retreat from their mistakes and let a storm blow over. There is always a camera or a microphone barrelling towards them. There will be a price for such an enormous flop.Pledges and policies are also inspected and dissected in the public square in a way they seldom are outside of an election. What starts the day on paper as a tidy soundbite can end it a disheveled mess. Positions that at first appear reasonable can turn to nonsense when chewed over at .Take Ms Sturgeonrsquos comments yesterday on having a democratic double-dip in . Out campaigning in Leith, the First Minister predicted a Labour government would grant a second independence referendum.Mr Corbyn has said he is open to it, subject to a few years delay to let Labour get underway in office, and provided it follows a democratic process, perhaps a fresh mandate in a Holyrood election. Ms Sturgeon seemed very confident.Talking to the media, she said: ldquoEveryone knows, you all know, therersquos going to be an independence referendum. The opposition parties might not yet have got round to conceding that point but they and know and everybody knows it.Ms Sturgeonrsquos dream scenario is a minority Labour government that needs SNP support to survive, giving her the leverage to secure Indyref.Labour counters that the SNPrsquos hand would not be as strong as it thinks. It has no nuclear option. Ms Sturgeon could hardly swing behind the ToriesLabour refused to oblige, or let the government fall and the Tories in. The SNP would be accused of another , when it helped oust Jim Callaghan and along came Margaret Thatcher.But a minority Labour government would not really be in a position to play hardball with the SNP. To legislate for the transformation Mr Corbyn promises, it would need the votes of SNP MPs. A deal between the SNP and Labour,not a formal coalition, seems a credible bet in such circumstances.But then Ms Sturgeon was asked a series of follow-up questions. The more her position was interrogated, the shakier it became. Would she compromise on her timetable of Indyref in the second half of   ldquoNo, Irsquove set out my timing. Is there a public appetite for two referendums in   ldquoYes. Is there a risk a Remain vote would diminish support for independence  ldquoNo, I donrsquot think so.Mr Corbyn claims he would get Brexit done in six months by having a Peoplersquos Vote. Which should come first - EU referendum or Indyref  Here Ms Sturgeon said something extraordinary. Apparently the order doesnrsquot matter.ldquoThe most important thing is not what comes first, itrsquos about why these things are important, ldquo she said.ldquoA second EU referendum is about giving the whole of the UK a chance to escape Brexit. A second referendum is about giving Scotland the chance that never, ever again, on Brexit or anything , do we find ourselves in a position where our future is being decided by the likes of Boris Johnson, not the people who live here.But the order is so obviously important itrsquos almost asthis stuff is being made up on the hoof. If Scots voted first for independence they wouldnrsquot get a vote on Brexit. The die would have been cast. Itrsquos also obvious Labour would prioritise its UK-wide promise on Brexit ahead of Indyref.So , in line with Ms Sturgeonrsquos plan, there were two votes in , it would be EU first then Indyref. But what would that look like  The SNP would have to campaign for Remain despite Brexit being the grounds for Indyref. Activists might be a bit queasy about unpicking their lsquotriple-lockrsquo mandate.Andthe result was Remain - and assuming Indyref wasnrsquot axed off as a consequence - the SNP would have to go back to the country immediately and argue it didnrsquot matter. Remain, Leave, whatever, we still need independence.That would echo early , when Ms Sturgeon first called for Indyref because of Brexit. She was ahead of public sentiment then. The two issues didnrsquot seem sufficiently linked to justy a new referendum, and the SNP was punished a few months later at the election for indecent haste.Since then, sentiment has moved in the SNPrsquos favour and independence and Brexit are seen as closely linked, the former offered as the way out of the latter. Ms Sturgeonrsquos efforts to fuse the two has paid off, with support for independence rising due almost entirely to No-Remainers becoming Yes-Remainers. Butshe gets her Remain result next year, she must convince a knackered nation to separate then again. Itrsquos a muddle.Ms Sturgeon might argue that, evenit is Remain, Scotland darenrsquot risk another Brexit-like disaster inside the Union. But whatrsquos like Brexit  Is there another white whale out there  Would voters be irresistibly drawn to more constitutional upheaval after settling four years of it just in case If thatrsquos the plan, I donrsquot think itrsquos only God whorsquoll be laughing.

title: fleabags-hot-priest-inspired-new-influencers
story: A vicar influencer who has been compared to Fleabags "hot priest" has said he is trying to "invade social media" with a message of hope.The Rev Chris Lee, , has more than , followers on an Instagram account on which he mixes snapshots of his home le featuring his we and daughters with "-second sermons" and theological musings."Social media is a tool, its neither good nor bad, but a lot of the time its used for a very vain pursuit in a superficial way," Mr Lee said."Im trying to invade that space with faith, with positivity, with hope."Most of the time what people see on Instagram is someone saying, look how beautul I am, look how good I am, and Im trying to say to the person watching, youre beautul or youre valued or youre loved."Mr Lee, who is the vicar at St Saviours Church in west London, came to the job by an unusual route.With a house, a mortgage and career in business by the age of , he found himself looking for something dferent and moved to Tanzania initially to teach English at a mission.With the Bible as his main teaching tool, he began "thinking more about God and hearing his voice", so he stayed and did a distance learning degree to become a priest, eventually being ordained a deacon in the diocese of Mount Kilimanjaro at the age of .At the time he moved to St Saviours four years ago, his brother-in-law was also setting up a couple of YouTube channels - Korean Englishman and Jolly - on which Mr Lee became a regular guest.As the channels took off, he found more people were starting to follow his personal Instagram account, so he made the decision to be "more intentional about talking to people about faith" - mixing his professional and private le."Thats the way a lot of young people are living, theyre living with this kind of avatar online and its very much part of how they see themselves and how they interact with the world," he said. "I was trying to do that but with faith at the core."While Mr Lee says he has avoided the vitriol and abuse that typies much of the discourse on social media, his increasing fame has brought some unwanted attention."Ive had some dodgy stuff sent to me - like some women sending me nudes or whatever," he said. "My we is like, right, block!"He has also had fans seeking him out during his services at St Saviours."I was asked for a selfie at a funeral I was doing, and that was fine but weird," he said.But he says attendances at his church have increased, and the majority of newcomers are sincere in their desire to learn more.As for the comparisons with Andrew Scotts much-lusted-after priest character from Phoebe Waller-Bridges Fleabag, he believes they come as much from what he is not as what he is.He said: "Im a young priest who is engaged with culture, so that in itself is going to raise eyebrows because priests traditionally are a little bit heavy, a little bit old and a little bit distant, and I am, I think, none of those things."While he enjoyed Fleabag and found Scotts character "fun and affable and engaging", he was disappointed to see him having a sexual relationship with the title character, saying: "I didnt recognise it as priestly at all."Mr Lee has become a prominent online voice for the Church of England, which he believes needs to do more to reach young people in digital spaces.His , Instagram followers vastly outnumber those who follow either the Archbishop of Canterbury or the church itself on the , while his slots on the Jolly YouTube channel can clock up to eight million views.As his audience continues to grow, he is happy to be offering something dferent in the social media space."People come to my account because they want a good news thing, they want to hear something that might affect them in a positive way," he said."Is that just another sense of consuming something  Maybe, but in a world where theyre told constantly they have to be sexual or they have to be popular, Im just trying to tell people youre loved as you are."

title: helicopters-4x4s-lifeboats-scotlands-rural-councils-prepare-december-poll
story: As Scotland prepares for the first general election in December for almost a century ndash and the first winter poll for more than four decades ndash councils across the country are gearing up for a mammoth logistical exercise.It might be the most wonderful time of the year, but it is also the wettest, the windiest, the coldest and the darkest.Peter Stanyon, chief executive of the Association of Electoral Administrators, told The Herald on Sunday the UK is ldquostepping into the unknown.Meanwhile, in the Western Isles, officials are reckoning with unpredictable weather, short daylight hours and a potential air traffic control strike meaning ballots canrsquot even be transported by plane on the night.Orkney and Shetland are grappling with similar issues, with bosses warning there is a limit to how much they can prepare.It is shaping up to be the most unpredictable election in decades. And itrsquos not just the political climate thatrsquos volatile.Derek Mackay, deputy ing officer for Comhairle nan Eilean Siar, said the highlands and islands ldquocould have signicant issues with a winter poll.He said: ldquoWeather is a major consideration. We often have challenges with a summer poll, never mind something in winter, because wersquove got to transport the ballot boxes and the ballot papers up from Barra to South Uist.ldquoSo yoursquore going across the Sound of Barra and the Sound of Harris ndash two stretches of water.ldquoWe always have a contingency arrangement for that, using boats, but that would obviously take pretty much till the next day before we get the papers there. So we usually use either a helicopter or a plane.If weather conditions are so severe that even boats canrsquot make it across, officials will simply have to wait.Mr Mackay added: ldquoWe have in the past looked at having the leboat in the Sound of Barra route,we can do that.ldquoIt is a shorter route, so it wonrsquot take the leboat far away from its normal base. But we just have to see what the weatherrsquos like on the day.ldquoIn the evening and in the morning, wersquoll obviously be watching the forecast well in advance so that we can make any logistical decisions.ldquoAndit is delayed, itrsquos delayed, but hopefully not for a signicant amount of time. But thatrsquos very much out of our hands. The risk is signicantly higher at this time of year.There is also the possibility of strike action by air traffic controllers employed by Highlands and Islands Airports Limited , amid an ongoing pay row.This could rule out using a plane, while helicopters can be weather-dependent.Mr Mackay continued: ldquoTherersquos also the issue of getting the ballot papers from the mainland to Stornoway and then on to Uist and Barra.ldquoWersquoll have contingency arrangements in place for that as well. That usually happens several days in advance of the poll.ldquoWe may have to bring that forward, depending on weather. So therersquos issues there.ldquoGetting postal packs to and from the islands,therersquos weather disruption with the Royal Mail ndash especiallyitrsquos on polling day, a lot of people could end up disenfranchised because their postal votes are stuck in Glasgow.Elsewhere, seasonal flu means more staff could be off sick, while officials are also looking at buying additional lighting to cope with the dark winter days.Mr Mackay said: ldquoWersquoll be meeting with the ious emergency services and our own technical services staff to look at options for their potentially having to have xs or all-terrain vehicles on the road.In , when the local government and Holyrood elections were held on the same day, last-minute fog grounded the helicopter on the Western Isles and delayed the count. And that was in May, not December.John Mundell, the interim chief executive of Orkney Islands Council and ing officer for Orkney and Shetland, said there is a ldquosignicant potential risk around the winter weather.Ferries could be cancelled, planes grounded and roads and footpaths covered with ice or snow.On Shetland, ballot boxes in the outer islands have be transported down to Sumburgh on the southern tip and then across the sea to Orkney, by plane or boat.Mr Mundell said: ldquoItrsquos unpredictable at the best of times, but during the winter you can get hit with all sorts that makes it even more unpredictable.ldquoItrsquos quite acute, and the risks are quite hefty. And obviously, from my perspective, Irsquoll be watching the weather forecasts very closely.Mr Mundell stressed ing officers up and down the country have been anticipating a winter election.He added: ldquoHowever, given the circumstances, there is a limit to what we can dowe are hit with the worst of the weather.ldquoObviously, the intention from the outset is to have the count completed in a professional and organised manner.ldquoBut under no circumstances will I be allowing my team to put lives or property at risk.Elsewhere, David Sutherland, Highland Councilrsquos elections manager, said a ldquomulti-agency coordinating group will be set up to assist with any events or incidents under severe conditions.He said: ldquoWe have been planning for a snap election for some time now and are very mindful of the possibilities of conducting an election in winter in the highlands of Scotland, which has the largest geographical election area in the UK with some of the most challenging distances to cover, including island communities.Scotlandrsquos cities also face a logistical juggling act to ensure everything runs smoothly.Both Glasgow and Edinburgh have been unable to secure their preferred venues for the election count due to the late notice.Andrew Kerr, chief executive of Edinburgh Council and the cityrsquos ing officer, oversees one of the largest operations in the UK, coordinating votes from five constituencies.He said: ldquoItrsquos not so much that itrsquos winter, itrsquos that now we donrsquot have very much notice before we go to the polls, with , polling cards going out.He said there are  polling stations to organise, with  staff manning them.A further  staff will be needed on the night of the count, which is likely to take place at the Royal Highland Centre in Ingliston.Mr Kerr said a small number of Christmas parties and other events had to be rescheduled to free up polling stations.He said: ldquoItrsquos just about getting yourself prepared. Itrsquos a big logistical exercise ndash a big complex logistical exercise.But he added: ldquoLocal governments all had some practice, I think, because of the European election, which were done at speed as well.ldquoSo wersquore just using the same protocols. Irsquove just stood up the full-time team again as of Monday. My election team ndash some of whom had gone back to their day jobs ndash are now back full-time.Peter Stanyon, chief executive of the Association of Electoral Administrators, said councils will need to use ldquoinnovative thinking.He said: ldquoWersquore stepping into the unknown, because we havenrsquot had a national poll in December since the s.He said there is a legal requirement to start counting the votes within four hours of polls closing.If this window is missed, he said, officials need to formally state the reasons for this.Mr Stanyon added: ldquoOne of the things that wersquove been talking to the Electoral Commission about is an understanding that, for exampletherersquos a heavy dump of snow, ortherersquos gales in the Northern Isles forecast for polling day, then clearly the count wonrsquot start within that four hour period. Itrsquos testing anyway, obviously, for the islands regardless.ldquoSo I think there will need to be a degree of understanding that every effort will be made to run this poll in exactly the same way asit were in the spring or summer months, but there will be that challenge.ldquoI know in the past, for example, when there have been weather issues, theyrsquove actually helicoptered the boxes in from the islands.He continued: ldquoThe good news, I suppose, is that ironically because of the European election, that we had been told wasnrsquot going to happen, the councils have been through this process recently.ldquoIf there had been any issues in the run up to the European elections, they will have been ironed out now in time for this particular poll. So there are some benefits that flow from that.

title: election-going-labour-love-workington-man
story: Itrsquos notable how campaigners suffered for years to get us the vote, even giving their lives. Indeed, they still do in benighted foreign lands. But, here, we complain that it might be too dark or a bit nippy and, evenit isnrsquot, we canrsquot be bothered because wersquove got busy schedules of reality TV to watch.And all this in the run-up to Christmas tae. The Dailycartoonist Matt quipped: ldquoAt least a December election will put paid to all that lsquoSeason of Goodwillrsquo nonsense.The cry also went up: ldquoBut what about the nativity plays  The what now  I havenrsquot been to school for a while, and never paid much attention when I was there. But are they seriously still forcing the inmates to re-enact scenes from the Middle East , years ago  Come to think of it, I canrsquot remember having these at my primary school. Maybe that was just Leith, right enough. I think we only did May Day and Leninrsquos birthday.It would be finethe election was all about Leith Man but the doughty old port suffers from the disadvantage of being Scottish and so could never be representative of Britain. Instead, theyrsquove decided that itrsquos Workington Man who should be the successor to previous incarnations of electoral barometer such as Essex Man and Worcester Woman, not to mention ious vehicular representatives such as Mondeo Man and White Van Man.The Pebbledash People were also adduced at one point, but the least said about them the better. In Leith, theyrsquod have been put up against a wall.The Workington Man concept comes from centre-right think-tank Onward, and is predicated on targeting older working-class Leave voters without degrees in gender studies or vegan sociology, who are worried about crime and immigration, which liberals living in prosperous, all-white areas say they ought just to thole.Itrsquos currently a Labour seat with an unrepresentative Remainer MP, which has led many stout proletarians to say theyrsquore going to vote Conservative this time. Thatrsquos well weird. But itrsquos the same in other northern English towns like Warrington and Wigan where, as one psephologist said, most voters would normally never give the Tories the steam from their tinkles.But now, feeling alienated from and despised by the haut-liberal establishment, many are thinking of going further than offering not just the vaporous by-products of micturition but also their votes.Not all of them are saying this, of course. Some Workington citizens have taken offence at the stereotype pinned to them, and many proletarian Leavers simply could never vote Conservative, even with clothes pegs on their proboscises.Itrsquos the latter vote that the Brexit Party of Mr Nigel Farridgeis banking on picking up. Yesterday, at the launch of their election campaign, the spiv-style statesman said that,the Tories thought they were going to win northern English Labour seats, they needed to get out of the office more.He believes his party are better placed to take the Labour Leave vote because, unlike the Tories, they donrsquot yet have a history of being horrible. The Brexit Party might plausibly claim also to be a broader church, apparently including even some ex-Communists, and as far as I can make out, it hasnrsquot overtly extolled the virtues of the enslaving free market as Boris Johnsonrsquos Tories do at every turn.Of course, a few people in Workington and where will continue voting Labour on a tribal basis, believing it still to be the party of the working person . The partyrsquos launch this week showcased several attractive proposals for punishing the rich, with even some encouraging talk that there should be no billionaires in Britain, and itrsquos possible that decent people everywhere might support this.But maybe not in Workington, which has had enough of Labour promises. Irsquom guessing that old industrial Leith, meanwhile, will stick with the SNP, particularly with its attractive policy on trans-gender issues.As for how Irsquom going to vote, Irsquom afraid itrsquos not my place to say.++++IF you were genuinely open-minded, and not a liberal, you might concede that there are some things to admire about Boris Johnson. Well, two: the humour and erudition.And, of course, there are a few things to dislike, including the not inconsiderable fact that hersquos a Tory. However, a clinching factor against him for many decent ratepayers is the fact that hersquos a cyclist. And,the account of one former journalistic colleague is anything to go by, he typies the breed.Stephen Robinson recalled: ldquo[Following] Boris on a bike is a very dangerous undertaking indeed. When traffic is gridlocked, Boris shimmies along the inside lane, propelling himself with his left foot along the kerb. He crosses red lights, he cuts up the largest lorries.Textbook stuff. Voting is an important business and, when weighing up candidates, it is important to consider several factors: their hairstyle, football team, alcohol intake and mode of transport.Few people beyond the pedalling narcissi themselves would knowingly vote for a cyclist. My own view is that, as with bald people, cyclists should not be allowed to vote never mind stand for election. However, Irsquom aware that this policy is not popular among the closed-minded.++++A SURVEY of , adults found the majority wouldnrsquot dream of going to the cinema or dining out on their own. The study, commissioned by hotel brand Staybridge Suites, also found many wouldnrsquot attend the pub or the football or a museum on their own.How peculiar. The only one I concur with is dining out. I used to do it when younger, not knowing it was problematic. But I soon noticed I was getting stared at by other diners, most often those couples who never exchange a word.Chinese restaurants were the worst. In two establishments, I looked up to find the entire staff staring. And they donrsquot flinch when you stare back.Of course, I cannot discount the possibility that I look bizarre. Somebody once said I resembled a character from The Lord of the Ringsand itrsquos true also that I used to be a martyr to red-face disease rosacea .But none of that is an excuse for such bovine staring. So,dining alone is called for, Irsquoll do it in rather than oot, thanks.++++WE live in fast times. By the time I finish this sentence, many of you online will already have moved on, to find something bilious about Brexit or fitbarsquo or dancing cats. Losers.However, I cannot say Irsquove been bothered by the furore over a new Netflix feature allowing viewers to speed up or slow down films and TV shows.Itrsquos mainly film-makers and actors whose underwear has been formed into a bent, curling or distorted shape by the development. They say the move has a similar effect on the artwork and resent such interference.But itrsquos long been available on DVDs, and I canrsquot remember using it much. On TVs, too, you can apparently fast-forward through the adverts on recorded programmes.The new Netflixis currently only available to Android users, ie punters with portable telephones. Am I getting this right  They watch movies on their mobile phones Why would anyone do that  Do they eat from tiny wee tubs of popcorn as well  Theyrsquore the sort who probably would fast-forward through films, right enough. The fast set. Still, therersquos no slowing down progress, Irsquom afraid. Right, Irsquom off to watch a video about a Brexit-supporting cat playing keepie-uppie.

title: alister-jack-even-snp-wins-scottish-seats-election-nicola-sturgeon-wont-mandate-indyref2
story: The Scottish Secretary, in an exclusive interview with The Herald at the start of the six-week election campaign, decried how the independence debate had helped sow deep ision in Scotland and declared: ldquoWe should take separation right off the agenda.While Mr Jack made clear he would ldquonot jump the gun about what would be in the Conservative manesto, his strong comments nonetheless did nothing to remove the idea that Boris Johnson would rule out facilitating a second vote on Scotlandrsquos future for the full five years of the next Parliament.After  days in office, the -year-old who was promoted to the Cabinet after only two years as an MP appears to be beginning to get the feel of high office as he sat in his grand ministerial bureau overlooking Horse Guards Parade and St Jamesrsquos Park.Less ebullient and more earnest than his predecessor David Mundell, ldquoUnion Jack, as he once referred to himself, is a steely Brexiteer determined to see Britainrsquos departure completed by January .But first the Conservatives have to win an election. The opinion polls, putting the Scottish Tories on just  per cent, down almost eight points since their impressive performance in , point to losses among their  seats where the SNP is the main challenger in all of them.But Mr Jack was having none of it, insisting that in fighting hard to retain all  Scottish seats, the Conservatives, by promoting themselves as the party of Brexit, could win more, possibly by getting supporters of Nigel Faragersquos party to switch to them.ldquoIf they back Brexit, the only party that is going to deliver Brexit out of this General Election is the Scottish Conservative Party. If you want Brexit, vote Conservative, declared the Secretary of State.He acknowledged: ldquoWe do start from  per cent but we also have the Brexit Party with six or seven per cent. We are the party that can deliver Brexit. We have a Brexit deal which we will be putting into our manesto and we will be the only party going to the electorate and saying give us a majority to get Brexit out of the way, get Brexit finished.But, of course, while Brexit might dominate the battle for No  south of the border, the perennial constitutional question is once again set to be at the forefront in the political fight north of it.With the SNP making clear that ldquoScotlandrsquos right to choose will be the central plank of its campaign, Mr Jack indicated that ldquostanding four-square against a second independence referendum would be at the heart of the Conservativesrsquo.A recent snapshot placed Scottish independence on  per cent support, causing the First Minister to claim that tide for Scotland breaking with the Union was on the rise.Askedshe was right to make the claim, the Scottish Secretary declared: ldquoI donrsquot accept that because the poll, which the Andrew Wilsonrsquos Commission suppressed, showed  per cent of those who voted to leave the UK in  have now changed their mind and the Survation poll that came out on the fth anniversary of the Scottish referendum on independence showed  per cent of the Scottish population wanted to remain in the United Kingdom.ldquoWe have a really strong case to put on that. Separation would be a terrible thing for Scotland. As we leave the EU we need to strengthen the Scottish economy and we will do that by taking away uncertainty, explained Mr Jack.Ms Sturgeon has insisted thatthe SNP got a majority of Scottish MPs at the election, then that would be an ldquoirresistible demand for indyref and the UK Govt would be dutybound to facilitate a second vote.ldquoNo, she absolutely would say that, wouldnrsquot she, declared the Cabinet minister.He argued that the Nationalist leader ldquopersistently finds reasons to promote independence and her call for a second vote to ldquodistract people from the real problem in Scotland, which is, after a decade in power, they have failed to improve our NHS, failed to improve our education service, failed to improve public services. So, they distract us by constantly harping on about independence.But askedhe was saying that evenMs Sturgeon and her party succeeded in getting a majority of Scots MPs at the election, they would not have a mandate for indyref, Mr Jack replied: ldquoIrsquom absolutely saying they would not have a mandate.ldquoTo me, itrsquos very simple. We had a once-in-a-generation, her words, once-in-a-letime, she and the First Minister at the time Alex Salmond used those expressions, referendum in , we had that, the people of Scotland decided to stay in the UK and they should respect that referendum and they should respect the referendum in , which was a UK one.He went on: ldquoWe do not need and we do not want to have another independence referendum. We should take separation right off the agenda, deliver Brexit, which got a majority of  votes in Parliament, the Second Reading of the Bill, come back, deliver Brexit and start focusing on the good things wersquore doing for Scotland the City and growth deals, bringing COP to Glasgow next year. Letrsquos start delivering on the good things we can do for the Scottish economy, growing that economy, growing peoplersquos prosperity as part of the UK.The Secretary of State stressed how Scotland had suffered the ldquodouble whammy of ision with the  and  votes and the task for a new Tory government would be to seek to heal the nation under Mr Johnsonrsquos premiership.ldquoBoth those referenda have been very isive but not just in terms of politics but in terms of families, relationships it has not been a good period in our history but we have to get Brexit sorted, push back the independence question, and start pulling together. We are all in the same rowing boat and letrsquos pull on the oars together. Thatrsquos my message.Last night, Ian Blackford for the SNP made clear thathis party did secure a majority of MPs in Scotland the UK Government could not stand in the way of indyref.ldquoAlister Jack has to recognise we already have a mandate for an independence referendum from the  elections. This time round we will be asking people to support Scotlandrsquos right to choose. The Conservatives cannot ignore democracy, he declared.In the interview, Mr Jack also said:*a new Tory Government would not seek to rush through a Withdrawal Bill in December as there would be ldquoenough time in January to do it*the Fixed-Term Parliaments Act, that restricts Governments in how to call an election, had ldquonot served us well in the last month and I would suggest we revisit it when we *eventhere had to be a ldquoflextension to the December  Implementation Period, the UK would leave the Common Fisheries Policy in  monthsrsquo time and*getting Brexit done would open up the ldquosunny uplands of potential trade deals with other countries.

title: nicola-sturgeon-independent-scotland-within-touching-distance
story: She said "another clear win" for the SNP at theGeneral Electionnext month will "bring it even closer still".The SNP leader is the headline speaker at the event in George Square, her first speech at an independence rally since the  independence referendum campaign.Ahead of the event, she said: "A vote for the SNP is a vote to escape Brexit, and to put Scotlands future in Scotlands hands - not Boris Johnsons."This election really is the most important one Scotland has faced in modern times."So much is on the line - people are completely fed up with the mess at Westminster."But George Square will be packed today as people from all backgrounds join together to demand a better future for Scotland."An independent Scotland is closer than it has ever been. It really is within touching distance.:Alister Jack: EvenSNP wins most Scottish seats in election Nicola Sturgeon wont have mandate for indyref"What is needed now is another clear win for the SNP to bring it even closer still - so vote SNP on December th to secure Scotlands right to decide."The First Minister used her speech to the SNP conference in Aberdeen to insist a second independence referendum "must" take place in .She will formally request the power for Holyrood to stage a referendum from Prime Minister Boris Johnson before the end of this year.A section  order - which the UK Government has so far refused to consider - would mean a legally binding ballot could be held.Also speaking at the rally, organised by Scotlands only pro-independence daily newspaper The National, are fellow SNP members Mhairi Black MP, Justice Secretary Humza Yousaf and Scottish Green co-leader Patrick Harvie.Mr Harvie will appeal for an "inclusive" campaign for a second independence referendum to protect people from the "hard-right Brexit project".Speaking ahead of the rally, he said: "The cause of Scottish independence must be broad and inclusive. Our ersity is our strength."Those people who are still to decide need to be offered a positive, hopeful vision about how we can live in a fair, equal, sustainable country, and why independence will help."But Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard insisted: "The last thing Scotland needs is another isive independence referendum.":Nicola Sturgeon says Labour will grant IndyrefMr Leonard, who will be campaigning in Coatbridge on Saturday, said: "While Nicola Sturgeon is speaking to her own supporters, Labour is out on the streets of Scotland speaking to voters."We are putting forward our positive case for a Labour government that will scrap Universal Credit, introduce a pound-per-hour real living wage and deliver pound billion of extra investment in Scotlands public services."Scottish Secretary Alister Jack meanwhile said the SNP would "absolutely" not have a mandate for a second independence referendumwins the most seats north of the border on December .The Tory MP told The Herald newspaper: "Im absolutely saying they would not have a mandate."To me its very simple. We had a once-in-a-generation, her words, once-in-a-letime, she and the First Minister at the time Alex Salmond used those expressions, referendum in , we had that, the people of Scotland decided to stay in the UK and they should respect that referendum and they should respect the referendum in , which was a UK one."

title: nicola-sturgeon-calls-scotlands-future-put-scotlands-hands-independence-rally
story: Nicola Sturgeon addressed crowds at the #IndyRef rally in Glasgow, organised by our sister paper The National.She told those gathered the time would come to break away from the chaos of Westminster in a second independence referendum in .It was the first time she had spoken at an independence rally since .: Live updates as massive independence rally gets underway in GlasgowShe told the crowds:"Over the next few weeks, it is our job to convince everyone we know to come out on December the th and send the biggest, loudest most resounding message to Westminster."That it is time for Scotland to choose our own future. It is time for Scotland to be an independent country."An independent country that will be the best of friends and family with our neighbours across the British Isles, across Europe and across the world."A privilege to speak in a packed George Square today at #indyref rally. Letrsquos put Scotlandrsquos future into Scotlandrsquos hands. ####### pic mzKMkJreYOrganisers The National said , people attended the rally.But Jeremy Corbyn said he would not back the First Ministers calls for a second independence referendumLabour won the election.He told reporters: "What I will say is that a Labour government will invest in Scotland, poundbn of capital investment in Scotland, as well as more money for Scotland through revenue spending which will help in terms of health and education, in particular.:Nicola Sturgeon: An independentScotlandis "within touching distance""And we want to see Scotlands economy improve and the levels of poverty in Scotland, particularly in big cities, Glasgow, Edinburgh and Dundee, being reduced."Its a Labour government that will do that. Scottish independence would mean a massive gap between what Scotland raises in taxation and what the Scottish people need at the present time."I think the much better option is a Labour government for the whole of the UK."

title: herald-writers-give-verdict-hometowns-health-check-experts-cambridge-university
story: Now,Herald writers have given their verdict on the places they call home.Do you agree  Whatrsquos your report on your town AyrAYR is a town with much going for it, from being the birthplace of Robert Burns to having one of the most characterful football grounds in Scotland.However, its huge challenges are well-illustrated by the once-grand but now-derelict Station Hotel building, which highlights Ayrrsquos importance as a market town in days gone by but also changing times.The seaside town, with its impressive waterfront from the town centre out to Greenan Castle, has had to adapt in recent decades to a transformation of tourism habits.Ayr is now having to adapt to an explosion of online retailing, and an increasing number of affluent commuters living in areas such as Alloway but working in Glasgow and spending their money at the likes of Silverburn.There is a view that, after some very trying times, investment in Ayr town centre is picking up. It is a fine and atmospheric town centre to walk around. Hopefully it can regain its vibrancy of bygone days.Ian McConnellCumbernauldIts a place where its reputation definitely precedes it ... a dump, a concrete nightmare, a Plook on the Plinth.But, really ... no, honestly ... Cumbernauld is actually a really good place to live. We moved our family there  years ago, our children have grown up there, and the fact they have thrived is in no small part down to their surroundings.Its relatively crime-free, its got good schools, good facilities, and no matter where you are theres green space just a stones throw away.The best thing  The transport links. Were  minutes walk from a railway station where we can go to Edinburgh or Glasgow, and the same distance from a bus stop that will get us into Glasgow in as little as  minutes .The worst thing  The town centre. Someone really needs to put it out of its misery, knock it down and build something that doesnt fill you with gloom every time you go there.Andy ClarkEast KilbrideEAST Kilbride is South Lanarkshirersquos largest town but is widely recognised for its enthusiasm towards roundabouts.When you tell a stranger thatrsquos where you live, it is the first thing they point out not the fact it was designated Scotlandrsquos first new town in May .It is a quiet place to live, appealing mainly to families with Calderglen and James Hamilton Park right on your doorstep.The village, which includes the oldest part of the town, offers independent restaurants and boutiques.While it might not be the busiest place to live, East Kilbride just is a -minute train journey away from Glasgow.Catherine HunterGreenockWhile it may have made headline news last month when cruise ship passengers staged a mutiny over visiting the town, Greenock is an area of historical importance to Scotland that still has a lot to offer, and remains popular with locals and tourists alike.A shipyard town that has been transformed into an urban area, the town maintains links to its roots and serves as a gateway for many cruise passengers to Scotland.However, it has also sought to strike a balance between being a port town and a modern town. Greenock has been in the grips of a transformation of late, with signicant investment put into the town centre with the likes of The Beacon and The Albany adding to the arts and culture hub in the town. And there is more investment to come that will see the main shopping area, The Oak Mall, to be transformed into a modern day outlet in the near future.While Greenock may have plenty to offer visitors with stunning vistas over the Clyde from the Lyle Hill or The Cut, it is also a town that is aware of what needs to change and is looking to build on its past to secure its future.Stephen McIlkennyLivingstonFrom the baffled looks on the faces of a few of my former Edinburgh colleagues when I told them I was moving to Livingston, you would have thought it was Pyongyang I was flitting to. To say West Lothian has a bad reputation amongst certain capital-centric, wannabe Establishment-types is a mild understatement. True, the region, a traditionally working class area famed for its mining, did take the full force of Thatcherite erarsquos post-industrial decline. Indeed, nearby Bathgatefeatured in The Proclaimers song Letter to America, which compared the impact of Tory economic policy to the Highland Clearances.However, moving to Livi has been one of the best decisions we, as a family, ever made. We live in the south of the town, Murieston, and are fortunate to have a beautul nature trail virtually on our doorstep. We may not have the cache of an ldquoaddress deemed so important in some more snobbish quarters, but we do live in a reasonably priced bungalow at a cost that would have secured only a mid-terrace home further east. The townrsquos main retail outlet, The Centre, is admittedly a Mecca for our consumerist society, but for families with young children it ticks all the boxes, offering convenience, iety and simply a place to go when itrsquos raining or too cold to venture out into the Great Outdoors.ThursoThurso holds the title of northernmost town on the British mainland as the gruelling eight-hour rail journey from Glasgow - via Inverness - will attest.The town historically ed as an important Norse port and had a reputation for its linen-cloth and tanning activities. Scrabster remains a hub for fishing, oil and tourism today, while nuclear power plant Dounreay - though mostly decommissioned by the end of the th century - still employs many locals.Thursorsquos laidback personality is comparable to island le while the town lacks amenities, it makes up with crisp air and rolling countryside. Le is slow, a little isolating even, but the area remains refreshingly unpretentious.Nicola Love
