title: glasgow-city-council-planning-152m-budget-black-hole
story: According to the local authoritys financial forecast, it is already planning for a gap of poundm next year, with gaps of poundm and poundm identied for the following two years.The councils finance chief has told councillors that opportunities to make savings and cuts are "becoming increasingly dficult" in the latest forecast, which predicts the Scottish Governments pay award will also decrease by poundm a year, over the next three years.Trade unions have now written to all councillors demanding any predicted gaps in their budget should not impact on workers pay and grading schemes, which are intended to address the equal pay issues which have affected the council for decades.Brian Smith, of trade union Unison, said the budget holes were "on top of around poundm in cuts to jobs and services in the last decade", and added: "This cannot go on."It comes after the Scottish Governments official forecaster said in May this year that the government would be facing a poundbn budget gap over the next three years, which could result in tax hikes and spending cuts to local services.The independent Scottish Fiscal Commissionsaid ldquoless money will be available for future Scottish budgets under a predicted shortfall in income tax receipts, described as a "devastating blow by critics.In a letter sent on Friday on behalf of all trade unions, Unison branch secretary Smith wrote: "The people of Glasgow, the services which they rely on and the workers who provide them are not to blame for the austerity politics of successive national governments or the decisions of previous Glasgow administrations to continuously defend gender pay inequality."A new pay and grading scheme to eliminate the scandal of gender pay inequality in our city will also be implemented over this period. The trade unions are clear that this will require signicant additional year-on-year revenue funding. The trade unions will fight using any means necessary to ensure this is delivered."The trade unions have continually opposed the passing on of Tory cuts and believe that the anti-austerity mandate which Glasgows, and indeed Scotlandrsquos, politicians have should be used to ensure no more cuts in council jobs and services."Much more could be done in the short term to hold off further cuts via borrowing powers, through the refinancing of PFI PPP deals, by the use of reserves and by the Scottish Government using its tax-raising powers more progressively."This would not be a panacea but a tactic to protect services while fighting for more money and revenue raising powers."The letter added that the Scottish Governments funding grants, which have been criticised by both Labour and the SNP in the past for being unfairly disadvantageous towards Glasgow, were going to further impact the city.It read: "The multi-faceted impacts on council services of higher levels of poverty and the city status of Glasgow are not sufficiently recognised at present."Glasgow City Council dismissed the criticism and said the forecast was a normal part of their financial planning arrangements.A spokesman said: ldquoAny local authority forecasts its budget lsquogaprsquo ndash which, in its simplest form, is the dference between income and planned expenditure.ldquoPrimarily, they are made up of inflationary and other fixed costs, such as pay awards. It is a normal part of the annual budget process to identy and then close those gaps.

title: no-swimming-sabbath-blow-campaign-open-lewis-pool-sunday
story: Two years ago, campaigners raised more than pound, from a crowdfunder to open Lewisrsquos public swimming pool and sports centre for a trial period on Sundays ndash only to be refused by the Western Isles Council .But now Families into Sport for Healthndash which wants Sunday access to the Ionad Spors Leodhaissports centre on a six-month trial basis ndash has offered todonorsrsquo money. It also invited suggestions for other good causes that could be instead given any unrefunded cash.The group, however, stressed that it would continue to campaign.ldquoAfter a lack of interest by CnES in a trial of Sunday hours of ISL, the volunteers at the FiSH committee are offering to refund the donations from contributors, said a message posted by FiSH.ldquoFiSH activities and campaigning will continue and the committee is looking for proposals for use of any unrefunded donations which will be used to benefit the health and wellbeing of children in the Western Isles .ldquoDonors wanting a refund and those wishing to propose use for funds are asked to contact FiSH at happyswimmingfish@gmail by December , .ldquoThe FiSH committee would like to thank all contributors and express disappointment at the lack of engagement by the local council after the efforts of all those who worked so hard to make this happen.ldquoThanks everyone. Keep swimming.The local authority said its decision not to open the site was for ldquooperational reasons and not a religious one.Council-run leisure centres on Lewis and neighbouring Harris are closed, although similar sites where in the Western Isles are open on Sundays.FiSH offered more than pound, it had raised to fund the pilot.It said the Western Isles had some of the lowest rates of participation in sport and exercise and some of the highest rates of childhood obesity in Scotland, as well as high overall body mass index rates.A previous survey showed that % of  sports centre users supported Sunday ISL opening and statistics taken from the indoors sports facilities in Uist and Barra reveal that people attend in highest numbers on Saturdays and Sundays, which is in line with the rest of Scotland.Protesters have in the past accused the council of refusing to open it for swimming and other sports because of religious reasons.Previously, councillors voted - against a yearrsquos trial run to open the Stornoway facility for three hours each Sunday due to the costs plus the lack of staff willing to work.The total included pound, from the National Secular Society ndash but that money has been ed.More than  campaigners previously tried to present the cheque in front of the Western Isles Councilrsquos headquarters in Stornoway ndash which is opposite the sports centre ndash but the council rejected the cash.It said the money should be ed or donated to charity.A council spokesman said: ldquoThere has been no change of policy in the councilrsquos position. The original decision was not based on finance alone, but also on operational reasons.The Rev Graeme Craig, minister of Free Church of ScotlandStornoway, said: ldquoI am sure that not only the local churches, but many who are not church-goers, will be grateful to CnES for maintaining the current, extensive opening hours of their sports facilities throughout Lewis while resisting the pressure from some groups to open ISL on a Sunday.ldquoA restful, quiet Sunday is a major contributor to the health and wellbeing of the whole community. Once facilities begin to open on a Sunday the pressure for others to open will inevitably follow.ldquoOne of the things which makes Lewis so attractive a place to live is that it has escaped the   rat-race which is the cause of so much stress and which strains both health and family le. It is my hope and prayer that a quiet Sunday will continue to be a distinctive part of our local culture.ldquoIt is something worth promoting and more needed than ever in todayrsquos busy world.Sunday cinema, which drew church protests during its initial trial, resumed permanently at the An Lanntair arts centre in Stornoway this year.Stornoway Golf Club is still battling its landowner, the Stornoway Trust, to play on Sundays and supermarkets and most other shops are closed on the Sabbath. Hotels, some restaurants and pubs and a filling station are open.The first Sabbath-busting ferry to Lewis came eight years ago, amid fierce protests. It has proved so popular that there are now two services on a Sunday for seven months of the year.An inter-island ferry between Harris and Berneray operates on Sundays after being introduced amid fierce protests in . Sunday flights to and from Stornoway started in .

title: reinventing-aberdeen-bid-put-sparkle-back-granite-citys-tourist-industry
story: For generations of holidaymakers, it was the Silver City with the Golden Sands. The pleasure beach carnival provided thrills and spills, there were donkey rides, high teas and dancing at the Beach Ballroom.Union Streetrsquos silver granite buildings offered a sparkling welcome to tens of thousands of visitors from Edinburgh, Glasgow and beyond who trooped off trains and buses or,they were very posh, a BEA flight to Aberdeen airport.So popular was the Granite City that at the height of a busy tourist season there could be as many as six trains arriving every eight minutes, each packed with up to  people.During a golden period of British seaside holidays before continental tourism dawned, the city was one of Scotlandrsquos most popular tourist destinations, while the castles, scenery and golf courses of the surrounding Aberdeenshire countryside kept the visitors coming.In Aberdeenrsquos case, an unfortunate delivery of contaminated Argentinian corned beef to a city shop in  proved disastrous. The subsequent typhoid epidemic left  people desperately sick, visitor numbers slumped and suddenly Aberdeenrsquos shining northern star was fading.Now, however, after decades of enjoying an oil and gas boom that more than made up for the loss of the Edinburgh and Glasgow Fair visitors, the Granite City and Aberdeenshire are preparing to become Scotlandrsquos next big tourist destinations.Stung by the downturn in the energy sector that saw demand slump for its once-packed hotel rooms, and perhaps slightly envious of Dundeersquos rising star as a ldquomust-see destination, Aberdeenshirersquos tourism sector is now seriously upping its game.Yesterday saw a major step towards the cityrsquos tourism rebirth with the reopening of Aberdeen Art Gallery following a pound. million revamp.Around , visitors were expected to pour inside the -year-old gallery to admire works by Tracey Emin, Henry Moore, Francis Bacon and Monet.Its  galleries offer three times the number of previous exhibits and include displays on nearby Balmoral and its links to Queen Victoria, the empowerment of women and the cityrsquos relationship with the sea.The galleryrsquos rejuvenation is accompanied by a host of other multi-million-pound new developments and revamps across the city, from the dramatic expansion of the cityrsquos harbour to welcome mega-size cruise ships, to a new look for Union Terrace Gardens.Along with the recent opening of the pound million Event Complex Aberdeen with its conference and venue space, restaurants and two new hotels with  new rooms, city leaders believe the city is set to shed a little of its ldquobusiness only image to lure a new generation of leisure visitors.That should be very welcome news for the arearsquos hotels. From enjoying the comfort of having rooms block-booked months in advance, many were left grasping for customers as oil and energy businesses slumped.Rooms lay empty, the cost of a nightrsquos stay in luxury hotels designed to meet high demands of big paying customers was slashed. Some, such as the -room Highland Hotel on Crown Street, closed.According to VisitScotland figures,  saw the volume of domestic visitors to Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire fall below , for the first time, driven by a % drop in business travellers.Meanwhile, BDOrsquos Hotels Britain report for the year showed the cityrsquos hotels had the worst occupancy rates in the country with more than one-third of rooms lying empty.It also recorded the biggest drop in rooms yield in the UK, with hotels earning pound. per room, down from pound. the previous year.The figures were particularly concerning at a time when rooms yield in Inverness grew by almost %, while Edinburgh soared by .%.Fast-forward to last month, and professional services specialist PwCrsquos latest Hotels Forecast report brought only some comfort. While a slight recovery in the oil and gas industry led to a .% increase in occupancy rates to .% in the past year, it is far short of the countless ldquono vacancies signs at the height of the oil boom when room occupancy rates were in the s and s.Despite the rise, revenue per available room was also said to have fallen by .%.Could Aberdeenrsquos multi-million-pound investments in visitor attractions and facilities bring the good times back ldquoUntil around , hotels had lsquono vacancyrsquo signs up, says Chris Foy, chief executive of VisitAberdeenshire.ldquoWe were doing very well from corporate business. But the city was hit hard and there have been quite challenging times in recent years.ldquoHowever, we are on the cusp of a renaissance in the city. We have seen some game-changing investments in the city and Aberdeenshire which are helping to reposition this part of the country as a short-break destination.ldquoWe are seeing tour operators with clients who are looking for something new, they want a high-quality experience and a high-quality hotel product. Aberdeen has , hotel rooms and the area has fantastic niche, luxury properties serving high-spending visitors. Therersquos plenty of capacity, the lsquono vacancyrsquo signs are down and there are fantastic deals.Foy believes Aberdeen and the surrounding areas can capitalise on a growing trend among travellers to embrace lesser-explored ldquosecondary cities which offer something dferent to well-trodden tourist centres.Evidence of that comes from Aberdeenrsquos recent surprise inclusion in the New York Times list of top  places in the world to visit alongside Doha, Los Angeles, Lyon in France, New York, Los Angeles and Tahiti.Meanwhile, accommodation giant Airbnb has also named Aberdeen as one of its top  trending global travel destinations for . The only UK city to appear on the list, it was praised for its ldquostriking cityscape, fine dining and rugged coastal scenery.Foy adds: ldquoTherersquos a realisation that therersquos another part of Scotland perhaps not as busy as some other areas. Aberdeen is a thriving energy city which is going through a transformation.Evidence of that seems to be around every corner ndash even at one of Aberdeenrsquos oldest buildings. Work has started on a major revamp of Provost Skenersquos House, built in the mid-th century ndash it is to become a visitor attraction where the lives of  famous Aberdonians will be celebrated, among them Annie Lennox and Denis Law.Aberdeen Science Centreis also set for a poundm upgrade to the old granite Tramsheds in the cityrsquos Constitution Street, while at the harbour, where for  years ships have brought visitors as well as supplies, a poundm expansion scheme is well under way.Once complete, the harbour will be able to welcome some of the biggest cruise ships in the world. Enterprising local travel agents have already confirmed new routes for the harbour, with vessels offering trips around Britain, to the Baltic States, St Petersburg, Norway and Iceland on the cards, while across Aberdeenshire tour companies are gearing up to cater for an influx of visitors seeking golf, castles and outdoor adventures.To help the area on its way ndash and following some criticism that its marketing strategies in the past have dwelled too much on certain other areas ndash national tourism body VisitScotland has included Aberdeen in a new six-month worldwide ldquoScotland Is Now marketing campaign targeting potential visitors from Germany, France, the US, China and the UK.Meanwhile, hopes are high that the decision to stage the BBC Sports Personality of the Year ceremony at the new Event Complex Aberdeen in December will give the area a national  for a sport-loving audience.City leaders are also looking at plans to host the final stage of the Tour of Britain next year and the cycling eventrsquos Grand Depart in  as a potential opening to encouraging adventure and outdoor tourism.All of this has led to local tourism agency, VisitAberdeenshire, calling for volunteer ambassadors for the area ndash people who can share their love and knowledge of the northeast to visitors.ldquoTourism in the northeast has been dwarfed by oil and gas in terms of the economy, agrees Councillor Jenny Laing, co-leader of Aberdeen City Council. ldquoThose in the city were happy to service the business market, but the downturn in oil and gas meant companies and their supply chains looked at how to cut their costs, and part of that was around accommodation.ldquoTherersquos an increase in the number of rooms available while the market has shted, she adds. ldquoWe have a great opportunity for tourism, wersquore close to the beautul coast, we have Royal Deeside, golf, castles, but we donrsquot have any joined-up approach about what we are offering.One idea is to present Aberdeenshire as Scotlandrsquos outdoor adventure destination, she points out.ldquoItrsquos about us finding a niche for Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire, collaborating and showing we have a good offering for tourists.Five hidden gems in the northeast. Footdee ndash locals pronounce it ldquoFittie ndash is a former fishing village just a stonersquos throw from Aberdeen Harbour. There are cottages, cobbled lanes and quirky touches, plus fresh seafood restaurants such as the Silver Darling at Pocra Quay serving the catch of the day.. Aberdeenshire has  miles of coast, towering sand dunes and a good share of championship golf courses ndash including two of the top  oldest courses in the world.. Off the beaten track on Royal Deeside sits Loch Muick on the Balmoral Estate which is home to ldquoVictoriarsquos secret. Glas-allt-Shiel was built as a quiet widowrsquos retreat following the death of her husband, Albert, and was where she spent time with her ghillie, John Brown. Nearby is Linn orsquo Dee, where the River Dee cuts through a granite gorge creating a torrent of water amid spectacular scenery.. Several peaks make up distinctive Bennachie hill on the outskirts of Inverurie, the best known of which is called ldquoMither Tap. Climb to the rocky granite summit to see the remains of a historic hill fort and for inspiring views of the surrounding landscape.. Aberdeenshire and Aberdeen are home to  castles, from Balmoral to the seven-storey pink-turreted Disney-style Craigie and Slains Castle, said to be the inspiration for Bram Stokerrsquos Dracula. Scotlandrsquos Castle Trail enables visitors to ldquobag up to  castles in the area.

title: scotlands-myths-legends-real-story
story: SAWNEY Bean the cannibal  Just anti-Scots propaganda. The Loch Ness Monster  Underwater gasses released from a seismic fault. Giants and elves  The result of our ancestors trying to make sense of Standing Stones and ancient burial mounds. Selkies and kelpies  Echoes of ancient rites such as human sacrice and animal worship.Scotland is rich in myth. Each tale, however, has a grain of historical truth lying at its heart. We may think of such legends simply as supernatural stories invented by ancestors with overactive imaginations way back in the mists of time, but in fact these fables all have some basis in fact ndash although itrsquos often hard to uncover.The same is true for any culture. Most myths across the world can be explained. Therersquos even an academic discipline for rationally interpreting legends ndash itrsquos called Euhemerism. This school of thought is so old that it goes as far back as the greatest myth-makers of all, the ancient Greeks.Such studies were inspired by Euhemerus, a gted thinker from the fourth century BC. He believed the Greek gods were merely ancient kings and queens who had become worshipped as deities over time. Euhemerus was certain that the real, mortal king who became known as Zeus was buried on Crete. He is seen as the first atheist in history.Archaeologists in the early-th century worked out that the Greek myth of the one-eyed giants called Cyclopes was inspired by the woolly mammoth. When ancient Greeks uncovered the remains of mammoths scattered across the Mediterranean, the skull would have been bewildering. It looked human, it was huge, and in the centre there seemed to be a single, giant eye socket. It was, of course, the cavity of the mammothrsquos trunk. But the myth of the Cyclopes was born.The dragon myth found across the world is down to our ancient ancestors uncovering fossilised dinosaurs and trying to make sense of their discoveries. Similarly, tales of the mythical Grfin originated along the route of the old Silk Road in Asia, where the remains of beaked dinosaurs and their eggs were found.In the book The Lore Of Scotland, folklorist Sophia Kingshill says the nationrsquos myths helped our ancestors ldquoexplain the world and take ldquocontrol over their surroundings and circumstances. In a world without science, the stories handed down to us as folklore were a very real attempt by our forebears to grapple with the mysteries of le.Folklorists have been trying to decode Scottish myths for decades, to unravel what might lie behind them. How do our myths reflect our own past culture, and the thinking of our ancestors Sawney BeanSometimes myths reflect not how a society thinks of itself, however, but how others see that society. One of our most monstrous legends, the story of Sawney Bean the Scottish cannibal, reveals how our closest neighbour, England, saw us centuries ago. Studying the Sawney Bean myth also reveals just how recently some legends have been created, and then quickly accepted as fact.The tale tells of a family led by Sawney Bean and his we who take to the caves around Girvan sometime in the s. The tribe turns to cannibalism, waylays local travellers, drags them into caves and eats them. Eventually, one traveller survives, and the king and his soldiers arrest the monsters in their lair, and execute the entire brood.Therersquos a spot near Bennane Head in South Ayrshire called Sawney Beanrsquos Cave to this day ndash however, therersquos no evidence whatsoever that the cannibal family ever existed. In fact, the first records of the tale appear in England in , when tensions were high between Scotland and England following the Acts of Union.Sawney Bean is first mentioned in a book called Lives And Actions Of The Most Famous Highwaymen, Murderers, Street-Robbers Etc written, we think, by Daniel Defoe of RobinsonTherersquos no mention of Sawney Bean in any Scottish sources, Hobbs points out, until  ndash by which time the legend was an established part of folklore.Loch Ness MonsterWhen it comes to Nessie it seems like science and religion may well have collided to produce one of the worldrsquos greatest monster myths.The first report of Nessie comes in the Le Of Saint Columba, written in the sixth century AD. It tells the story of the Irish monk who brought Christianity to Scotland. It canrsquot have been easy converting the Picts, but claims of supernatural powers always help. Columba was said to have defeated a Pictish wizard, and repelled a monstrous ldquowater beast at the northern end of Loch Ness.Columba battling a monster from a river or loch would have been highly signicant to the ancient Celtic mind. Rivers were among the most important deities in the Celtic religion. A prominent Celtic goddess in Britain and Ireland was Danu, the mother goddess. Danu is also the root of the name for the river Danube ndash showing the extent of Celtic faith across the continent.Stories of Columba overpowering wizards and river monsters would have acted as propaganda at the time and accelerated his mission to convert Scotland ndash but there might also be a grain of truth somewhere too. Italian scientist Luigi Piccardi investigated possible geological explanations behind myths. He was interested in the fact that the Columba legend says the monster appeared ldquocum ingenti fremitu or ldquowith loud roaring. Loch Ness sits on the Great Glen Fault and itrsquos thought what Columba claimed to have seen was a mini-underwater earthquake, or the release of gas.Giants and fairy folkThe landscape around Scotland is filled with Standing Stones, burial mounds and ancient hill forts. To a Scot in the Middle Ages, such sights would be almost impossible to explain. What were they  Who had built them  Perhaps, our ancestors theorised, they were the work of giants or the entrance to Fairyland. In the th century, the Normans thought Stonehenge was built by giants.Therersquos been speculation that the word ldquoPict might be the source of the word ldquoPixie. This could be the ultimate source for ldquoPuck ndash the fairy made famous by Shakespeare in A Midsummer Nightrsquos Dream. Strange Pictish carvings are found on stones across Scotland. Itrsquos thought our ancestors interpreted these carvings as the handiwork of fairies.If we had no understanding of Neolithic le or the Bronze or Iron Age, such ideas would give meaning to the unexplainable.One of the most famous examples of the Stone Age-inspiring myths comes in the shape of ldquoElf Shot. When farmers in the medieval period were ploughing their land they would often uncover Neolithic arrow heads. Of course, no-one knew of the Stone Age back then, so no-one could understand what these strange stone arrows were ndash unless, of course, they were weapons used by fairies.During one battle in  at Loch Gruinart, there were claims that little people ndash an eighth the size of humans ndash helped the winning side. The legend is thought to be down to elf shot found in the area.Fingalrsquos Cave on the island of Staffa in the Inner Hebrides is a perfect example of the landscape-affecting myth. Itrsquos an incredible and imposing geological feature ndash and to the minds of our ancestors it could easily be seen as the home of some huge giant. In Irish mythology, Fingal is the warrior giant Fionn MacCumhaill ndash or Finn MacCool. Like many ancient mythic figures, itrsquos thought he was based on a great king or warlord who became a god-like figure long after his death.Legend has it that Fingal erected the standing stones at Machrie Moor on the Isle of Arran. Some of these spectacular stones stand nearly five metres high. Without an understanding of the past and of science, how  could our ancestors have interpreted the stones  They had to be the work of giant hands.Fingal is supposed to have died in Scotland ndash maybe in Glen Dochart. The fact that an Irish myth has such strong Scottish connections points to the deep cultural links between Ireland and Scotland going back millennia. The ancient kingdom of Dal Riata, founded in the fth century, spread from the north of Ireland across the west coast of Scotland. The prevalence of Irish myths in Scotland is a cultural reminder of our shared history.The Cailleach was a female giant also inspired by the Scottish landscape. The island of Ailsa Craig is supposed to be a pebble which fell from her apron. Huge stones in the Forest of Mar in Aberdeenshire were said to be the remains of her home.Rocks at the Falls of Connel are stepping stones she used to cross Loch Etive. There were reports of sightings of the Cailleach well into the Victorian era and she was last seen around  near Lochaber.In Scotland, therersquos also a long tradition of ldquoBrownie stories ndash of elf-like creatures who come into homes at night and perform good deeds, such as mending clothes or sweeping floors. Similar stories exist throughout Europe ndash most famously in the tale The Elves And The Shoemaker where little people help a cobbler with his work at night. Itrsquos believed these stories may be a hangover from the time when most of the continent was ruled by the Roman Empire. Romans believed in ldquoLares ndash household spirits which looked after every family, and often helped out in times of need.In Shetland and Orkney, stories of the little people reflect the regionrsquos ancient Viking past. On the islands, little people are known as ldquotrows ndash a derivation of the Scandinavian ldquotroll. These creatures lived in hillocks or cairns. One such place is the Trowie Knowe, a chambered tomb in Shetland.Sometimes, tales of the little people were a way of explaining the most painful of events. If a perfectly healthy baby dies today, we realise it is cot death. A millennium ago, such a tragedy would be impossible to understand. However, parents could find some explanation in the malevolent actions of fairies who came into homes, stole human babies and left dead fairies in their place ndash so-called changelings.Kelpies and selkiesMany myths across the world began as stories told to children by their parents to scare them and keep them safe. Think of the bogeyman stories of the th century. Some of these tales have morphed over recent decades, and taken on the shape of myths, such as the online Slenderman legend. Slenderman was taken so seriously by some children in America in  that the story led to violence.The kelpie may well be the original Scottish bogeyman. Itrsquos also a myth that could only be created in a country dominated by water. Scotlandrsquos rugged and sprawling coastline and myriad lochs and rivers made this a dangerous place to live in ancient times. Unlike many other parts of Europe,you lived in Scotland in the Stone Age or Bronze Age you were going to have to travel by boat a lot.The kelpie was a terrying horse-like beast which lived in water and would drag you to your death. One of the most famous kelpie stories sees seven little girls and one boy playing in Glen Keltney. The little girls see a horse in the loch and climb on to its back. The boy refuses. The girls drown. The boy lives. The moral of the story, children, is do what your parents tell you and stay away from water.The kelpie myth is also an echo of the ancient Celtic practice of making sacrices to appease powerful water gods who lived in rivers. In some cases the sacricial victim would be a horse. To make more signicant offerings to the gods, humans would be sacriced, even children.Like kelpies, selkies also played a role in reminding people to be respectfully fearful of water, but these mermaid-like creatures, half-human half-seal, say more about ancient economics and religion. Along the Scottish coastline, and across the islands, the seal was a vital resource for our ancestors. It provided food and clothing. Humans have hunted them since the Stone Age. Neolithic people identied closely with the creatures they hunted, and even worshipped them. Their shamans, or priests, would ldquobecome the deer or seal during magical ceremonies to help in the hunt. Once killed the animal would be revered because of the importance of its sacrice to the tribe.In the s, a North Uist poet, John MacCodrum, claimed he was a selkie descendant. In the sea, selkies take the shape of seals, on land they take off their skins and assume human form. However,they lose their skin they have to remain human. The North Uist legend tells of a local man who fell in love with a selkie and stole her sealskin to keep her on land. The couple had children but one day the selkie found her skin and ed to the sea.Their descendants were known as ldquothe MacCodrums of the Seals. In the th century on North Uist there were still people who claimed a lineage back to selkies.On Orkney, there were stories of people descended from selkies being born with webbed hands. Perhaps that myth was inspired by the birth of a disabled child. After all, our ancient ancestors found source material for the legends they handed down to us wherever they looked.

title: general-election-2019-labour-win-itll-less-like-venezuela-britain-circa-1974
story: Jeremy Corbyn was also talking tough this week. He identied some of the capitalist criminals Labour is coming for, including Sir Jim Ratclfe of Ineos. Though itrsquos not clear under what law the polluting plutocrats could be prosecuted.So, is this class war in the UK  Are we on the road to Venezuela  Whatever the polls say, a Labour victory this Christmas is quite possible with Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party now splitting the Tory vote. There is a powerful mood for change in Britain. But what would a Labour government actually look like We have never had such an avowedly radical Prime Minister ndash not even in , when Labour was led by a small ldquoc conservative, Clement Attlee. However, Labour reality would be rather dferent from the rhetoric. Burrow into Labourrsquos policies, and what emerges looks more like reheated social democracy, circa, than a Bolshevik revolution.For a start, we can largely ignore the issue that ided the party so bitterly in recent times: nuclear weapons. Jeremy Corbyn may be a lelong member of CND, but Labour is no longer a unilateralist party. Its  manesto committed a Labour government to renewing Trident almost indefinitely.But Corbyn will still enter Number  with a raft of left-wing policies, from seizing corporate assets to abolishing private schools as well as taxing the rich until the pips squeak. However, many of the headline policies will never make it to first reading, let alone the statute book.Abolishing schools like Eton would involve y court action, not least from faith schools and the home school movement, who might also be affected. Labour is more likely to confine its assault on educational privilege to axeing tax reliefs worth about pound. billionSimilarly, seizing % of the shares of companies with more than  employees would be fiercely resisted in the courts by shareholders. They have deep pockets. I suspect Labour would confine itself to increasing corporate taxes, ending zero-hours contracts and restoring trades union rights ndash all of which are eminently doable.Indeed, looking behind the radical rhetoric, much of Labourrsquos policy agenda is surprisingly modest, viewed from Scotland. Measures like free personal care, abolishing university tuition fees, childcare for three and four-year-olds, scrapping the right to buy, lting the benefits cap and the bedroom tax ndash these are all achievable.Indeed, the Scottish Parliament has already achieved them, bar the welfare cap. Nicola Sturgeon will no doubt remind the Labour leader of this repeatedly in coming weeks.Nationalisation is a policy that used to be seen as ldquoloony left but is no longer. Taking rail into public ownership shouldnrsquot be too much of a problem, since Network Rail, which owns the track and signalling, is already in public hands. The service franchises could be replaced as they come up for renewal, without needing to hand billions in compensation to Virgin and the rest.Waterand energy would pose greater problems, not least because most of our energy companies are foreign-owned ndash often, ironically, by state-owned bodies. But with a good wind it should be possible for Labour to find a way. Public attitudes to public ownership of utilities have changed out of all recognition since the s.Similarly, there is broad public support for Labourrsquos Green New Deal. A majority of voters agrees there is a climate emergency. Though they may not agree with the measures needed to tackle it.Labour is not going the full Extinction Rebellion route of making Britain zero carbon by . But its own policy, passed at conference, is still pretty radical. It commits a Labour government to making Britain zero carbon by . Thatrsquos only five years longer.We are talking about the most radical change to our lestyles since the industrial revolution. Labourrsquos policy would mean decarbonising transport, home heating and agriculture in a decade. Millions of cars would have to be scrapped along with millions of home boilers. Air travel would all but cease.Labour promises a huge investment in renewable industries to compensate, but that is unlikely to replace the jobs lost in the car industry, oil and gas, road haulage and retail.So expect the Green New Deal to become somewhat lighter green in government. There is likely to be a rt between the Thunberg-supporting ldquode-growthers and Labour MPs, who traditionally see economic growth as the best way to address poverty and inequality.However, Britain already has a rather good record on eliminating greenhouse emissions, and this will continue, albeit with the  target reduced to % net zero.In sum, Labour offers a practical social democratic programme which could be very attractive to voters, especially younger ones. However there is one very big problem: Brexit.Labour is committed to negotiating a new Withdrawal Deal to replace Boris Johnsonrsquosand to putting this to another Brexit referendum. This will consume a vast amount of political capital and will surely dominate the first year of a Labour government.Corbyn wants to reintroduce the customs union and Brussels would probably agree to that. But Labour also wants close regulatory alignment with the European Single Market, which the EU  would probably reject. If Britain wants to be in the single market, it will have to join the single market, probably via the European Economic Area, along with Norway.Labour could go along with that in the end, since it wants friction-free access to the EU markets. Single market membership would solve the Irish border problem, for sure.But it would also mean Britain continuing to contribute to the EU Budget, while having no say over decisions taken by Brussels. Customs union membership requires oversight by the European Court of Justice, which will displease many.But that wouldnrsquot be the main problem. If Labour got this wonderful deal, including workersrsquo rights and environmental standards, and got it through Parliament , would it really then campaign against it in the confirmatory referendum Interviewers have largely stopped asking this question, because they never get an answer, but Europe remains a huge question mark hanging over Labourrsquos government agenda.Labour is still a Brexit party, though you wouldnrsquot know it to listen to most MPs. Many figures in the party are closet Brexiteers, like Jeremy Corbyn himself. Others are openly pro-Brexit, like the party chairman Ian Lavery and the MPs who voted for Boris Johnsonrsquos deal.Equally dedicated Remainers ndash mostly Blairites and supporters of the deputy leader Tom Watson ndash would fight back, insisting that Labour effectively promised to back Remain in the General Election. Brexit wrangling could delay the confirmatory referendum and ide the party, just as it split the Tories.Corbynrsquos enemies will ignite further ision by condemning him as anti-Semitic. It will take immense powers of leadership to prevent a Labour government being halted in its radical tracks by Brexit.The question for voters is: does Jeremy Corbyn possess it

title: glasgow-university-honours-father-japanese-whisky
story: And now the le of Masataka Taketsuru is to be celebrated at the university where he first enrolled to learn the art of his trade a century ago.The University of Glasgowrsquos Adam Smith Business School is to host an evening reception and exhibition in honour of the achievements of the man credited with introducing the water of le to the Land of the Rising Sun.Today, Japanese whisky is a multi-billion-dollar industry with the Suntory distilleryrsquos Hibiki -year-old blend a regular recipient of the Worldrsquos Best Blended Whisky title at the World Whisky Awards.So big has it grown that the Far Eastern ieties now rival those in whiskyrsquos native land, and it was all made possible by Taketsurursquos passion for spirits.Masataka Taketsuru was born to a highly traditional sake-brewing family from Takehara, a coastal town  miles east of Hiroshima, in .It is said that as a boy he was involved in a scuffle during which he suffered a particularly violent blow to his nose, which left the young Masataka exceptionally sensitive to smell, a talent he later used to identy dozens of dferent whisky brands by their aroma.Although he was expected to take his place in the family firm he joined another company, Settsu Shozo, after graduating with a degree in fermentation, and from there developed his plan to bring whisky to the Japanese market, which until then had shown little interest in the drink.Arriving during the winter of  aged just , he was taken in by the Cowan family of Kirkintilloch as a lodger and enrolled in the universityrsquos summer chemistry programme while also studying at the Mitchell Library in his spare time, translating Nettletonrsquos seminal tome, The Manufacture of Spirits in the Distilleries of the United Kingdom, into Japanese.In the spring of , he gained his first hands-on experience of whisky-making with a five-day apprenticeship at the Longmorn distillery in Speyside and later at Borsquoness with the master distiller James Calder.But whisky was not the only thing Masataka would come to love about Scotland. A friendship with his landladyrsquos daughter Rita had blossomed into something more romantic and the pair were married in , despite the staunch disapproval of both their families.Rita Cowan, at , was living a le of faded prosperity with her mother and three siblings after the death of her father, Dr Samuel Campbell Cowan, the previous year, and seized the chance to break away from her tight-knit community even though it would mean uprooting herself to the other side of the world.Masataka had already marked himself out as an unusual man, but his mixed marriage was highly unorthodox in his home country, where arranged marriages were seen as the essential ingredient of a happy and successful le and Westerners were few and far between.According to family legend, the couple slipped away and married in a register office without the knowledge or permission of either of their sets of parents. Ritarsquos -year-old sister and her friend acted as witnesses and the diminutive party ate an illicit celebratory meal afterwards at the nearby Station Hotel.But despite its clandestine start, the marriage would prove to be a success, with Rita accepting the customs of Japan when she emigrated there with her husband later that year.The couple later adopted two children ndash a daughter, Rima, whose name combined Rita and Masataka ndash and a son, Takeshi, who was Taketsurursquos orphaned nephew. Takeshi, who would go on to inherit Masatakarsquos whisky business, witnessed the atomic blast at Hiroshima from his home nearby.Back in Japan, Masataka put his new-found distilling skills to use with a job at spirits maker Suntory.However, whisky was slow to catch on in the Japanese market and it wasnrsquot until  that the breakthrough was made.Establishing a distillery at Yoichi on the island of Hokkaido, which has a similar climate to Scotland, Mastaka began to produce a drink that found a ready market. Some of the recipes he introduced remain firm favourites today, such as Kakubin ldquosquare bottle, the most successful of all Japanese whiskies.In , with a gulf growing between Japan and the West which would soon erupt into war, homegrown whisky rose in popularity and Suntory became the official supplier to the Japanese navy.The distillery, with Masataka its guiding light, was then ideally placed to capitalise on the economic boom which gripped Japan as it rebuilt in the s, and a huge consumer class arose hungry for luxury goods.Rita died in , and Mastaka in , after a le which saw him awarded six honours from the Emperor and his hometown, and gain the unofficial title of ldquothe father of Japanese whisky. Kirkintilloch, where he met the love of his le, is now twinned with Yoichi, which has a ldquoRita Road among its street plan.Dr Niall Mackenzie of the University of Glasgow Adam Smith Business School said: ldquoMasataka Taketsuru is one of the universityrsquos many illustrious and world-changing alumni ndash the centenary of his enrolment at the University of Glasgow is an occasion for celebrating his role in the creation of Japanrsquos whisky industry and the longstanding connections between the university and Japan.The celebration of Masatakarsquos Taketsurursquos le will be held on November  at the University of Glasgowrsquos Kelvin Gallery.

title: thriving-surviving-dying-scottish-towns-health-check
story: ldquoI have a soft spot for Berwick-upon-Tweed, he says, referring to the home of the only technically English club in the Scottish league. ldquoThere are a lot of great towns, Aberdeen, Dundee.But Leishman warms up as he gets closer to home. ldquoLook at Falkland, Culross, these places are fantastic. Look at the East Neuk of Fe. St Andrews is beautul.The Labour councillor represents Dunfermline ndash and a new academic report from the Bennett Institute for Public Policy at Cambridge University underlines just how well this Fe boom town is doing.Scotlandrsquos ancient capital, Dunfermline is also the fastest growing ndash and fastest improving in the country, according to a detailed crunching of government statistics.Leishman is not surprised. And he dials up his pride to reflect this. ldquoIt is a lovely place, Dunfermline.ldquoWe have the new bridge and the circle line in Fe. The expansion of Dunfermline has been amazing with people ndash first-time buyers or people from Edinburgh coming across and getting more value for their money.But Leishman recognises that there is a problem in Scotland: we no longer talk about our towns. We fret about islands and remote Highlands. We focus on the economic engine houses of our cities. And we neglect the dozens of communities where so many of us live and work.Some of these communities are not doing well. The new Cambridge University report reveals a very mixed bag of results for Scottish towns, especially some of the post-industrial ones. ldquoMost towns on the west coast of Scotland are declining faster than the average British town, its authors conclude. ldquoAyrshire and areas along the river Clyde appear to be a hotspot for town decline.They are talking about communities such as Dumbarton, Irvine, Greenock and even Troon, some of which at least match Dunfermline for their historical pedigree.But Leishman has advice for fellow civic leaders. ldquoJust keep the pride in your town, in where you are from, keep the heritage. I am a proud Fer, especially of Lochgelly, my hometown. We should not be afraid to speak about the positives.Towns are unfashionable, at least for policymakers. So much so that some of Scotlandrsquos most town-like towns ndash the kind geographers use as case studies ndash have been jostling to be redesignated as cities. Stirling, Perth and Inverness have all successfully secured city status. This seems to please some politicians. Geographers roll their eyes.The latest research sets aside such eccentricities, harmless as they may be.A town, for geographers, is an urban settlement with a population of between , and , or so. Council borders ndash such as between Glasgow and Rutherglen ndash or local name signs, such as the border between and Gourock and Greenock, are not important for this kind of analysis.And so Scotland has three real city conurbations, Glasgow, Edinburgh and Aberdeen, and  distinct towns, from relatively big Dundee to Whitburn in West Lothian.Michael Kenny, the professor who leads the Bennett Institute, admits there is wiggle room over definitions.He said: ldquoWhat some people will call a town, other people will call a city. The two things blur in to each other.ldquoFor the statistical stuff, we use a technical definition. A town is a place that exists separately from a large city, that has its own identity and its own sense that people feel they belong to them, and they are smaller than a city.ldquoOver the last two decades in Britain and in many other countries the dominant assumption is you can achieve growth through cities.ldquoAlmost inevitably that led to towns and other communities moving to the margins of the attention of policy makers. I donrsquot think that was always deliberate. But towns fell from view.ldquoA number of towns have quite rightly read the runes and seen that in the world of government funding and focus, being a city or a city region is a better route to getting resources.ldquoThere is something  here as well, which is that some of these places, and Dunfermline is a good example, are seeing rapid shts in population and feel more like cities.Kenny and his colleague Ben Goodair have been crunching numbers across Britain. They are looking at things like levels of deprivation and jobs density ndash how many posts there are per person in a town. And they have watched populations wax and wane. So Greenock shrinks and Dunfermline grows.Amid the bigger picture, there are hard truths. Scotlandrsquos towns are poor. ldquoThree-quarters have more household deprivation than the average British town, concludes the report. ldquoMeanwhile, towns in Scotland also appear to have lower numbers of some key public services. There are fewer nursery schools, mental health practitioners and health services compared to the British average.ldquoThe sparsity of these services is indicative of lacklustre town centres and struggling local economies.There is only one of the  towns with no police station . Only six lack a fire station. Yet centralisation under successive governments mean there are many with no hospital.The authors suggest things are getting better for public services in towns. ldquoIn terms of changes to public service numbers between  and , its towns outperform those in England and Wales ... and, of the top  British towns with the most increases in public service provision,  of them are Scottish.Sometimes services ndash such as transport ndash are based around historical population patterns. The report cites Greenock as an example. ldquoAs a key centre of manufacturing, shipbuilding and mining since the th century, Greenock has  train stations. This serves as a useful reminder that levels of service provision are sometimes the result of longer historical patterns, not just current policy choices.ldquoOverall Scotlandrsquos towns have experienced a reduction in the number of their services in key areas such as education, culture and emergency services, quite often because these have been consolidated in larger urban areas. In some cases, councils have merged schools, or lsquosupercampusrsquo, in the hopes of reducing costs. ldquoAberdeenshire Council reports nine recent consultations on reforming school provision through mergers, moving campuses and changing catchment areas.The reality is that towns y. A lot. Those that still have jobs are doing well. Only six of the  towns have more jobs than people of working age: oil town Westhill in Aberdeenshire, Inverurie, Inverness and Culloden, Elgin, Livingston and Perth. Dumfries, Fraserburgh, Stirling and Glenrothes are not far behind.But jobs do not necessarily mean wealth. Some dormitory or retirement towns, or those that are a mix ndash such as Helensburgh, Linlithgow, Stonehaven, Carnoustie and Ellon ndash can have low levels of deprivation despite low or medium levels of local employment.Kenny and Goodair suggest this iety means there is no one-size-fixes-all solution. Their reports says: ldquoThe wide geographic spread of towns in Scotland means that there is a iety of kinds of town. Understanding the dferent needs of these ndash for instance those that are struggling on the west coast, compared to its more prosperous lsquoworking townsrsquo in the northeast and the belt of residential, commuter towns around large cities ndash is a prerequisite for more effective policy responses.In England, the focus on towns comes after Brexit, after the chattering classes noticed that town dwellers and the left-behind of small urban centres voted Leave. Kenny added: ldquoWe are seeing a turn back to look at towns because certainly in England the jolt of Brexit has provoked some soul-searching.The Federation of Small Businesses is one of the few bodies demanding more attention for towns, Brexit or not. Its spokesman, Craig Borland, said: ldquoThis report shows our towns remain a mixed bag, with some offering unique and vibrant locations to live, work and do business. However, many towns still bear the scars of deindustrialisation and continue to struggle with that legacy, especially in the west.ldquoIf we want to improve the economic fortunes of our hard-pressed towns, we need to tackle the root causes of their challenges. And, at the core of that, is generating and maintaining a critical mass of economic activity ndash spreading their risk across several economic sectors making it easier to start up and run a business making it the first choice for consumers ending their abandonment by banks and the public sector. All of that, of course, requires long-term funding and support.Politicians will be spending a lot of time in towns this month as they hit the campaign trail. They can expect to hear a lot about bus stops, banks and post offices, job centres, supermarkets, train, fire and police stations and all the other amenities that make a town a town. most deprived townsbull Cowdenbeath, Lochgelly and Lumphinnansbull Methil, Leven and Buckhavenbull Stranraerbull Whitburnbull Greenockbull Larkhallbull Kilsythbull Irvinebull Hawickbull PrestonpansTown health check: three success storiesBy the reports authorsFalkirkFalkirk scores best of any town in Britain on our index of changes to public service numbers between  and .By our measures, Falkirk can be categorised as an improving town, an isolated town and a working town. This means it has better economic improvement relative to other British towns, sits further away from a city than most and has more jobs per resident within its boundary than most.Falkirk benefits from being a large town giving it multiple economic strengths. As the largest town in the Falkirk council area, it acts as a hub of services and employment for residents of Falkirk and nearby areas. Industries such as oil and manufacturing are a strength in Falkirk, Scotlandrsquos only crude oil refinery is located in nearby Grangemouth.Falkirk also benefits from being on the main Edinburgh to Glasgow train line.ElginThis is the sixth most remote town in Scotland in terms of its distance to a nearby city. However, it has had economic growth better than most towns, has more jobs per resident than most towns and is in the top  British towns for increases in numbers of public services since .Elgin stands out in our dataset for having particularly high numbers of jobs per resident. The Royal Air Force has traditionally provided a large proportion of these jobs. RAF Lossiemouth air base contributing around , jobs alone. Elginrsquos ability to retain high numbers of employees while being a very isolated and small town means that it stands out in our report.PerthPerth is another ldquosuccess story for scoring well across our board of measures. The town is one of the better growing economies in Scotland based on our Improvement Index. Perth is also one of the towns with the highest numbers of jobs per resident and, like Elgin, has lower rates of household deprivation than most Scottish towns .Perth comes fourth highest in our index of changes to public service numbers.Perth is not as large as Falkirk but still acts as an employment hub. The town is home to the headquarters of Scottish and Southern Energy and Stagecoach whilst Highland Spring is located down the road in Blackford.

title: birds put on a show at forvie reserve
story: Photographers have captured stunning images of wild geese and waders flocking to a local nature reserve.Images taken at Scottish Natural Heritagenational nature reserve at Forvie reveal the mass migration of wild birds from Iceland, Greenland and Svalbard.Stuart MacQuarrie, SNH’s Head of Nature Reserves, said: “To see a flock of geese as they lt off from their night-time roost is one of Scotland’s greatest wildle spectacles. It’s such a remarkable aerial display, made even better by the chorus of their high-pitched calls.“These amazing birds migrate as far as , miles to reach Scotland for their winter feeding, before ing to more northern climes in the spring. And there’s plenty of time for people to come out to one of our nature reserves over the next few months and see this marvellous display for themselves.” At Forvie, there are about  waders, including  dferent species, on the Ythan estuary over autumn. There are good numbers of redshanks, lapwings, curlews, dunlins, golden plovers and oyster catchers. An occasional rarity also shows up at Forvie, this year including a great egret, ten common cranes – and a terek sandpiper, only the second ever spotted in North East Scotland and the th in Scotland.The best places to watch them are from the hide at Waulkmill or the two laybys that overlook the estuary north of Newburgh on the A, where you can use your car as a hide and watch the undisturbed birds. There are also good views to be had by parking at theWaterside car parkand walking down the north side of the river on the Dune Trail.SNH’s Forvie reserve manage, David Pickett, explains:“These fantastic viewpoints make the Ythan one of the most accessible birdwatching spots in Scotland for waders.The best time to watch these amazing birds is approaching high tide, as the water is moving the birds closer to you.”For more info about Forvie nature reserve see:www.nnr-scotland.org.uk.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Engineers installing the two concrete shafts"  Progress at Kintore rail station site viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: expansion plans set to boost kintore businesses
story: Two Kintore-based businesses are set to more than double in size and create around  jobs with ambitious six-figure expansion plans.Husband and we team, James and Rebecca Carr, who run Kintore Car Sales and Rebecca Carr Hair Salon, are expanding both businesses to enhance their offering in the area.Mr Carr has moved his car sales and valeting firm to a two-acre site adjacent to his other facility which has quadrupled the size of his business footprint, allowing him to add a new servicing ision to the business.The move has already seen the headcount increase to five with plans to double staff numbers to support the continuing expansion of the seven-year-old business.Mrs Carr, who launched her salon in  which has  employees and more than , clients, is set to expand into a purpose-designed, sq ft building on the site of the previous car sales courtyard, in addition to continuing to operate her current salon in the village’s Midmill Parade.The new venture, Rebecca Carr Residence, will add a beauty lounge to the services, with the venue set to include private beauty rooms, in addition to pedicure stations, a nail and brow bar, make-up artist station and a retail gt section.The ‘Residence’ will also boast a café with outdoor space which will be run by fellow local business, From Bakery Lane, and will also boast private customer parking.The renovation, which is title: focus on families at inverurie centre
story: Garioch Sports Centre in Inverurie has announced they are adding a Family Membership to their existing offering.The new membership will be available as a Black Friday deal throughout the month of November as part of Garioch Sports Centre’s ‘Black November’ initiative.The membership will launch on Friday, November  and will be available to purchase until Saturday, November .Kevin Bonarius, Chief Operating Officer, said: "Our Family Membership has been a long time coming. We’re proud to be more than just a gym, we’re a family facility and that’s at the heart of everything we do."Our Family Membership incorporates the very best from our existing fitness memberships coupled with kids and teens activities too."Families will be able to enjoy gym access, unlimited access to over  fitness class each week, teen gym and kid’s activities alongside reduced rates for personal training, creche, court hire and all of the benefits of GSCrewards – our new member benefit scheme."Kevin added: "Our Family Membership is a cost-effective way for families to stay active and enjoy exercise together. title: inverurie retailer wins big in london
story: An independent Inverurie retailer has been given a prestigious award for quality and service in London.Booth Scotland was awarded the coveted ERT Award for ‘Best Independent Consumer Electronics Retailer – Large’ at the  Awards presentation in London’s Covent Gardenearlier this month.Taking place in the Grand Connaught Room’s, entrants were subject to assessment from a  of industry experts who judged the retailer categories.Booth Scotland’s Inverurie store offer’s the newest cutting-edge consumer electronics, with large modern display areas offering the customer a hands-on environment to test and try products.Winning an ERT Award recognises the knowledge of their experienced staff and speaks for the standard of service they provide.Trevor Booth director at Booth Scotland was delighted to be presented the award and said: “Booth Scotland continue to strive to deliver high quality products and services within the North-East of Scotland. “We are delighted to be recognised for this hard work, it means a lot to our team who continuously put in the hours and effort to provide for our customers. “We look forward to seeing how we can continue to develop and push the standards of consumer electronics within the retail industry.”General manager Allan Will was also in attendance to be presented with the award, he said “It’s great to see the North-East of Scotland considered and recognised for an award judged and presented in the UK’s capital city. “This will be a great moral boost for the team back in Inverurie, who equally deserve recognition for this award.”Now in its  th year, the ERT Awards bring together retailers and suppliers to recognise excellence across the electrical retail industry. title: progress at kintore rail station site
story: The new Kintore station is taking shape with engineers installing the concrete shafts for its accessible footbridge.The two ten-metre-tall, eight-ton structures were craned into position this week.Network Rail, and main contractor BAM Nuttall, are constructing the new £.m facility to reconnect Kintore to the rail network for the first time in  years.Funded by Transport Scotland, Aberdeenshire Council and Nestrans, the new station will have step-free access between s through the new footbridge and lts.Facilities at the station will also include a -space car park, including spaces for electric vehicles and disabled parking, bike storage facilities and connections into the local bus network.Kintore is due to enter service in May  and all Aberdeen-Inverness trains will call at the station.The original Kintore station opened in , but closed in  as part of the Beeching cuts.Reopening Kintore has been made possible by the double-tracking of the line between Aberdeen-Inverurie delivered as part of the Aberdeen-Inverness Improvement Project.Funded by the Scottish Government, the Aberdeen-Inverness Improvement Project is increasing capacity on the route between the two cities so more trains can run on the line.Graeme Stewart, Network Rail Senior Sponsor for the project, said: “The new Kintore station will reconnect the local community to the rail network for the first time in nearly six decades.“The construction of the new station is progressing to plan and we look forward to delivering the facility – and the travel opportunities it creates – for customers.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: shire bear hunt proves popular with youngsters
story: Throughout the summer holidays, more than  knitted bears were hidden in localcommunities where there is a Live Le Aberdeenshire library.It formed part of the continued celebrations of the th anniversary since the publication of children’s classic, “We’re Going on a Bear Hunt”.More than  knitted bears werehiding, just waiting to be foundFamilies were asked to pick up an entry form from their local library before venturing out to find six hidden bears.Once they had been discovered and their locations recorded on the entry form, families handed the cards back to library staff.They were then entered into a prize draw, with the winner and their family helping donate the bears to emergency services and charities.More than  children and their families took part in the “bear hunt” and Gregor and Cameron from Inverurie were the lucky winners.They were at Inverurie Library recently to sort through the bears and help allocate them to deserving new homes.Some bears have already been donated to good causes and some libraries have hung on to a few to give out to borrowers who deserve a furry hug.So far bears used in the project have been committed to the Children st charity and to the Waterberry Community in Zambia. title: campaign highlights road safety
story: As winter#s dark nights draw in Police Scotland are looking to shine a light on safety for vulnerable road users with new campaign Operation CEDAR.The initiative being run across the Highlands and Islands Division is aimed at improving road safety across the region. In Orkney, Police have joined up with Orkney Road Safety forum, to encourage cyclists to remain safe and visible, with not only education, but the handing out of bike lights.Police are reminding cyclists that along with obeying all traffic signs, traffic light signals and not cycling on pavements, they must equip their bikes with the appropriate lights and make sure they are lit when it starts to get dark.Officers in Orkney will be proactively looking to address cyclists who ignore the legislative requirement to illuminate their bikes in darkness, and will be providing bike lights to those who need them. Just over  pairs of bike lights have been purchased using funding from Police Scotland Safer Communities for this purpose.#Visibility is key to keeping cyclists safe on the roads and I would encourage cyclists to ensure they wear bright reflective clothing and illuminate lights on their bikes, both front and rear, in order to make themselves more visible to other road users,# said chief inspector, Matthew Webb.#This is equally applicable during the day, but more important at dusk and when it#s dark, to avoid collisions and warn other road users to their presence.#Some cyclists wear dark clothing and particularly on faster roads they can be almost invisible to drivers until they are close to them.#He added: #I recognise in this rural community that a lot of the measures are equally applicable to the equine community and they are more than welcome to make use of the same free offer.#This initiative has been supported by the Orkney Road Safety Forum who will assist with the distribution of these lights, which in addition to the police office, are available from the OIC hubs and Scottish Fire and Rescue Service Community Safety Advocacy.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: second measles case confirmed onboard northlink ferry
story: A second measles case has been confirmed, linked to a Serco NorthLink Ferries service between Shetland, Kirkwall and Aberdeen.NHS Shetland has this week issued a “warn and inform” message to all passengers who travelled on three dates, including a northbound sailing which called in at Kirkwall.Those who disembarked and embarked the ferry in Orkney on Saturday, October , have been warned that they may have come into contact with the highly-infectious virus, say NHS Shetland.As well as the Saturday, October  sailing, warnings have been issued for all passengers who travelled on the southbound and northbound sailings on Sunday and Monday, October  and , which did not call in past Orkney.All crew members who travelled on the three dates have been notied.NHS Shetland is working with other relevant authorities including Health Protection Scotland to ensure that all control measure are in place to prevent further spread of the disease.The only way to prevent the spread of measles is to have the MMR vaccination, of which two doses is required to ensure full protection. It is possible that subsequent cases of measles could arise in susceptible passengers who have not been vaccinated.Measles is most common among young children who have not been fully immunised, and the disease can be spread through direct contact or through the air when they cough or sneeze.Passengers who travelled on the ferry are asked to be vigilant and content their GP or Public Health teamsthey develop a:copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
